With so many different organisations from around the world on the ground in Aceh and with so much work to do, one of the problems has been not only keeping a track of who is doing what but, disappointingly it seems, competition between aid agencies for the most prestigious work and duplication may be reducing the effectiveness of some aid efforts in Aceh. Also of concern are reports that the Indonesian government's concerns about the presence of foreign aid workers in Aceh may lead to a restriction in access for Australian aid workers. Any unreasonable restriction would hamper the ability of aid agencies to deliver the programs they asked the Australian people to support and in response to which the Australian people so warmly responded. Of course, access must be contingent always on an appropriate provision of security for those delivering the aid. Expectations are therefore high that the money so generously donated by the Australian people will be used as intended. That is important in terms of keeping trust and faith with the Australian people during the month of December and January when they gave so generously; it will also be important in terms of ensuring the generosity of the Australian people in the future when other natural disasters, regrettably, occur. While we appreciate that the fact that the brunt of the Tsunami was felt in the middle of a conflict zone and that this poses security problems for the Indonesian government, we also believe that this presents some opportunity for dealing with a long standing and, at times, intractable security problem in Aceh. We would urge the Indonesian government to seize the opportunity presented by this tragedy to rebuild not only the infrastructure of the province of Aceh but also Acehnese difcivil society and to make the most of this opportunity to reduce separatist tensions in the province and to bring about a lasting peace settlement. All countries of goodwill, all friends of Indonesia, would hope that the radical change in circumstances in Aceh which has occurred as a result of the tsunami would provide a basis for an enduring peace settlement. The aid package to Indonesia should therefore be seen as an opportunity to strengthen the relationship rather than as an exercise of Australian influence per se. Of course the potential for such positive developments in the bilateral relationship must be warmly embraced in the wake of, frankly, a tumultuous period in Australia's bilateral relations with Indonesia during the course of the Howard government. The strength of Australia's ties with its nearest neighbour has been consistently challenged by a number of the foreign policy statements and initiatives on the part of the Prime Minister. We have had the Howard doctrine, where the Prime Minister, in the period subsequent to the East Timor operation, stated that Australia should act in South-East Asia as a US deputy sheriff. At the time, that particular statement by the Prime Minister went down like a lead balloon across South-East Asia and in Indonesia in particular. The Howard doctrine, so called, is still seminared upon in various Indonesian universities and still talked about within Indonesian elites and society more broadly as indicative of where the Prime Minister's overarching foreign policy priorities lie. The original version of the Howard doctrine was further enhanced when the Prime Minister added the second plank-namely, his doctrine of regional military pre-emption. The Prime Minister publicly-and, in our judgment, irresponsibly-speculated about the possibility of future pre-emptive military strikes against our neighbours in South-East Asia. Is it any wonder that we had such significant and adverse political reactions from so many regional capitals? Just when the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, thought he had done all that he could to mop up the considerable diplomatic fallout from the Prime Minister's irresponsible comments on both these questions, in the heat of the federal election campaign the Prime Minister again came over, in terms of his overall posturing on the security needs of the region, in a manner which did not play well in regional capitals and did not add substantively to Australia's inherent national security priorities and interests. The two planks of the so-called Howard doctrine were announced publicly, with a firm eye on Australia's domestic political agenda, but they came at the expense of Australia's long-term foreign policy interests in the region, which are core to this country's long-term national security interests. These are important questions for Australia's long term relationship with Indonesia and the region, and it is hoped in the post-tsunami period of our relationship with Indonesia that lessons are learned by this Prime Minister and this government in how to deal more effectively with Jakarta in the future. Recently again, however, an opportunity was presented to make amends for some of these errors in the past and to put our relationship with Indonesia and the region on a new footing. Unfortunately, when this occurred in the case of the proposal for Australia to consider signing the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, the Prime Minister once again indicated that he was not only lukewarm on the idea but in fact not inclined to support it at all. This again played badly with regional governments, particularly when they discovered that other allies of the United States, including the Republic of Korea and Japan, had found no difficulty whatsoever in signing the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation with the 10 countries of South-East Asia in order to place their countries' relationships with the South-East Asian region on a long-term institutional footing. Again, Labor would call upon the Prime Minister to review his position on that as further meetings with ASEAN occur in the year ahead. The government sent officials to consult with the United States and the United Kingdom on the development of its latest maritime security policy, but did so in a way which did not adequately bring our friends in Indonesia into the loop in terms of how any changes to Australian maritime and strategic doctrine may affect the long-term security relationship which we have with Jakarta. In all of these examples, the point at issue is this: whereas improvements have occurred in the Australia-Indonesia relationship as a consequence of the government's entirely positive handling of the natural disaster brought about by the tsunami, underneath that there are still enduring tensions in this relationship which have been caused by a series of foreign policy actions by the government which need to be dealt with fundamentally if we are to have a sustainable basis for our relationship with Jakarta in the future. Our position on this is that there is no more important regional relationship for Australia in South-East Asia than our relationship with Jakarta. Australia's national security interests have always attached fundamental priority to our relationship with Indonesia. If you look back to the period of the Second World War, Australia's national security interests were immediately shaped by actions which occurred in the then Dutch East Indies, as the strategic pathway to Australia. Nothing has changed in terms of this country's national geo-strategic circumstances. It behoves, therefore, any government of Australia-Liberal or Labor-to ensure that our relationship with Jakarta is placed in the best order possible. Therefore, the challenge again-and I say this in the strongest possible terms to the House-is to ensure that the good legacy which has been left by our handling of the tsunami is now built upon and that the mistakes of the past are not simply repeated, thereby undoing the good work which has now been done. Of course we have a long-term interest in South-East Asia as far as the war against terrorism is concerned as well. Here, we must be concerned about winning the battle for hearts and minds. This is a point which we in the Australian Labor Party have repeatedly emphasised not only to this government but to other governments over a long period. Our ability to confront terrorism in South-East Asia has in part depended upon the prosecution of two simultaneous campaigns. One is to enhance the capabilities of countries in South-East Asia to deal effectively with the policing, border control, immigration and intelligence related concerns in dealing with terrorist organisations or emerging terrorist organisations in their area. That is an area of work which still has much to be done within it. There are still huge capability gaps across the region which need to be addressed. I say again to this parliament that we need a comprehensive counter-terrorism strategy in South-East Asia to ensure that that work is done-that there are proper, region-wide border security arrangements, that there are proper, region-wide intelligence-sharing arrangements and that there are proper, regionwide police capabilities in place, so that when terrorists are identified they can be tracked down, captured and prosecuted. That is one part of such an effective strategy. The other part is the battle for hearts and minds. Terrorist organisations are able to recruit in many impoverished parts of South East Asia because underlying social and economic conditions and political conditions make it easy for them to recruit. It is therefore important that any balanced and therefore comprehensive counter-terrorism strategy deals with this as well. That brings me back to the question of the tsunami and Australia's response to it. Plainly, through Australia's action on the tsunami, the Indonesian people in part have seen a government and people in this country responding at a humanitarian level to the needs of ordinary Indonesians right across the archipelago, particularly in Aceh and most particularly in Banda Aceh. This is to the good. But the key challenge is to ensure that that message actually reaches the whole of the Indonesian people so that those Indonesians-young Indonesians, unemployed Indonesians-who are forming part of radical militant Islamist organisations see evidence themselves that this country and its people have given generously to our friends and our brothers and sisters in Indonesia in their time of need. Part of the challenge is that the mass media in Indonesia have not uniformly ensured that that message has got through to the Indonesian people. The simple message and challenge for us in this parliament is: if we are extending $1 billion worth of assistance to the Indonesian people, are we conveying that message to the broader Indonesian community in a way which leaves a lasting legacy in our long term battle for Indonesian hearts and minds in the wider war against terrorism? The challenge that I place before the government today is as follows. We have had this extraordinary event, this tsunami. The response by the Australian people, the Australian parliament and the Australian government has been equally extraordinary. But we need a mechanism available to us to get the message out. This government, for reasons I have never understood, has removed from itself the principal mechanism available to it to transmit our message to wider South-East and East Asia-namely, Radio Australia. Not long ago, before this government was first elected, Radio Australia was one of the most powerful shortwave transmitting organisations in the world. Through the Cox Peninsula transmitters, we were able to extend a sound footprint right across South-East Asia, right across East Asia and almost into Central Asia, and across the entire Pacific, including Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia. You could pick up Radio Australia's signals easily in Beijing. You could pick them up in Pakistan. You could certainly pick them up with great strength right across the Indonesian archipelago. But as a consequence of two things-firstly, the sale by the Howard government of the Cox Peninsula transmitters to a Christian evangelical organisation and, secondly, the radical reduction in funding for Indonesian language programs through the remaining Radio Australia serhere vice-we have now taken from ourselves our capacity to effectively broadcast our message through our radio system to the Indonesian people. At present, because we have a reduced transmission capability, now limited primarily to Shepparton in Victoria rather than Cox Peninsula off Darwin, our ability to transmit a signal is effectively limited to eastern Indonesia-the eastern part of the archipelago-and to Melanesia. If you look at the map, the problem for us is that Sumatra is not in eastern Indonesia; it is in western Indonesia. Therefore the ability of Radio Austo it tralia today-this day in March 2005-to send a strong and continuing signal to Sumatra and Aceh in bahasa Indonesia explaining precisely what the Australian government has done, rightly, in response to this disaster is highly limited. The only way in which Radio Australia seek to make up for this is to beg, borrow and steal broadcasting space and time, which they pay for at commercial rates, from other private transmitters in other private operations. This is not nearly as effective, comprehensive or continuing as having a professional Radio Australia service dedicated to that end. My call to the Australian government is a genuine one. It is not driven by partisan political concern of any description. Radio Australia, I say to members opposite, was Menzies' child. Menzies created Radio Australia-from memory, it was in 1939 or 1940. When we were in government, we built upon it. Other national broadcasters, whether it is Deutsche Welle, Radio Nederland, the Voice of America or the BBC, have all added to their global shortwave transmission capabilities right across the world. Why are they doing that when we, at the same time, are reducing our transmission capability? It is very simple. They recognise that, across the rural communities in particular of developing Asia, shortwave is still the principal means by which people get news. Furthermore, if you are able to use a substantial transmission footprint with a clear signal, with regular programs so that people know when to tune in, and to do so with regular language programs in the principal languages of the region, then you are able-over a period of not just months, not just years, but decades-to construct an image for Australia in the region which reflects who we are as a people and, particularly in terms of our response to the tsunami, what we have done to assist the people of Indonesia and Aceh at this particularly difficult time. As the government considers its options for the upcoming federal budget, I simply lay before it this challenge: in the various priorioperation. ties you assess in terms of expenditure, it is important that you seize this opportunity to set to rights what I think is one of the worse decisions you have made. The situation which presents itself in the post-tsunami period provides a classic opportunity for doing that. If you fail to do so, my concern is that the good work that you in the government and we, the country and the people of Australia, have done will simply be wasted and lost on the Indonesian people. When I was in Jakarta in January, and subsequently in Banda Aceh, I visited the Australian Defence Force and saw the work they were doing on the ground. I was told by officials at our embassy in Jakarta that the Indonesian language media's coverage of Australia's contribution to the clean-up in Banda Aceh was much more muted than the reality warranted but, because we did not have our own capacity to project our message through Radio Australia, we had no other means of getting the message out. This is a genuine foreign policy tragedy. Our challenge beyond the immediate issues of the tsunami and how we punch that message through to those communities across rural Indonesia that might otherwise, over time, be tempted to lend various forms of tacit, indirect or even direct support to the emergence of further terrorist organisations like Jemaah Islamiah is to ensure that that does not occur, by getting out a positive and strong message about what we in this country are doing. I repeat: we are in the battle for hearts and minds in Indonesia. To succeed in that, we need good policy from the government, as its response to the tsunami has been, and we do not need a repetition of bad policy of the past. I have referred to the Howard doctrine and the doctrine of regional military pre-emption and others, including the Prime Minister's refusal to give consideration to signing ASEAN's Treaty of Amity and CoBeyond all that, we need a capacity to get our message out, and Radio Australia presents precisely that. Through the minister at the table to his colleagues in the cabinet, I say: consider the Cox Peninsula transmitters and getting a decent transmissions capacity back for Australia when you consider options for expenditure later in the year; and consider rebuilding the Indonesian language services of Radio Australia and, beyond that, services in the other principal languages of the region, including Chinese. This would mean that our enduring achievement from our response to the tsunami would lend itself to the long term foreign policy benefit of the nation. I therefore commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: I am very keen to add my support to the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005. The Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005 provides appropriation to replenish funding for programs, including programs in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and AusAID, Australia's overseas development agency, which was diverted to enable the emergency response to those horrendous and epic events that surrounded the tsunami. The passage of these bills will ensure that the government's emergency response is not funded from other priority programs and will underpin the government's commitment, in partnership with the Indonesian government, to supporting Indonesia's reconstruction and development. Our initial response was rapid, generous and appropriate. We chose as a nation not to wait but to attend to the needs of a neighbour facing a crisis; it was characterised in the media as seeing your neighbour's house burning but not waiting for the council to give you the green light to go and help. The need was obvious and Australia, along with partners with the capacity and the tools available, responded very quickly. In hindsight, those who criticised our responsiveness as being not in keeping with a more coordinated arrangement will look back and think that that response was entirely appropriate, very timely and very much welcomed and needed. We were able to rapidly deploy consular personnel, personnel from AusAID, the Defence Force and federal and state police and other staff to assist in the days following the 26 December disaster, which was a natural disaster of epic proportions, the human cost of which continues to unfold. Over 300 officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade were deployed to help deal with this crisis, including 150 of those fine individuals-outstanding public servants, every one of them-who were recalled from leave to make a very meaningful and substantial contribution to the effort. Many of them have been working in Canberra, but 36 staff were also dispatched to Thailand to establish temporary consular offices and liaise with the local authorities and citizens helping Australians. We provided crisis management and emergency hotline services around the clock, coordinating the Australian government's response. Staff from other agencies, including Centrelink, the Protective Security Coordination Centre, Customs, the Department of Transport and Regional Services and Austrade, were all brought into assist with over 84,000 phone calls from Australians concerned for their families and loved ones who may have been in the affected areas. I would like to put on the record my admiration and praise for the remarkable effort of the consular team of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and all of those officials and coordinating and collaborating agencies for a remarkable job. They are extraordinary individuals who were working in very difficult circumstances. I am pleased to know that, if Australians are in need overseas, we have people of such high calibre standing ready to provide whatever assistance we are able. In the weeks following the disaster, in collaboration with state, territory and federal police and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was able to confirm the safety of over 14,300 Australians originally reported to its consular hotline. We continue to give the highest priority to assisting Australians caught up in disaster, families who lost loved ones and particularly those who are still waiting for their loved ones to be identified. Our early financial contribution of $60 million in emergency relief through AusAID was focused on supporting direct assistance to communities in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, the Maldives and other affected areas. In addition to those resources, civilian medical teams made a priceless contribution of expertise in primary health and preventative health which is often not reported on. We know the loss of life that the moving water caused and that still water poses an enormous threat of waterborne diseases such as cholera. Our expertise from state, federal and territory governments and from the private sector made a remarkable contribution in helping local authorities on the ground guard against still water having the same horrendous effect that moving water had caused. We had expertise made available to assess the damage to the coral reef. Another untold story is the horrendous impact that this natural disaster has had on nature herself. These are some of the most blessed parts of our planet. Many Australians are very fond of these regions; they are places where dreams are played out, where idyllic holidays are had and where adventures are enjoyed. But nature has been very unkind to herself. The coral reef and the marine ecosystems in these areas have taken an absolute hammering and, as countries seek to rebuild themselves and communities seek to re-establish livelihoods, those who rely upon the sea look out at that thing that caused them such grief and know that the sea itself has been damaged. I spoke with the President of the Seychelles and he said, with tears welling in his eyes, that the first thing that children hear when they are born in his country is the sound of the sea. Their culture, their livelihoods and many of the stories that are passed down from generathe tion to generation come from the sea. People's livelihoods centre on the sea, whether it be in the fishing industry or in the tourism industry and the like. The President spoke of how many of his citizens now fear the very thing that gives them the essence of their being. Our people are helping to assess what nature has done in terms of damage to herself around coral reefs and the marine ecosystems. Those remarkable people who work in and in collaboration with the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research are sharing their expertise. There is an exercise going on call ground-truthing. I did not know what ground-truthing meant until I spoke with the ACIAR team. They are actually trying to work out what is now the reality on the ground. I mentioned what the marine ecosystems have had done to them, but in the areas where we are working the very coastal zones themselves have changed. The inundation of what I call the ‘marine muck', the debris and the sediment that has washed on to those areas, has changed not only the topography of those areas but the soil structures. Once you knew you could successfully grow a particular crop for years and years; now it is not clear what those soils will produce, what harvest they will get or what bounty and nourishment they will provide for their citizens. That work continues, and we know in some of those areas that for years ahead the soil composition will not be as it was, and work needs to be done to understand those changes and how to move forward. The Treasurer, in his excellent second reading speech, has already identified some of the key elements of the Australian government's relief effort. I would like to mention some other important efforts that are being undertaken. Australian-aid-funded experts including logisticians and engineers were critical in enabling key international organisations such as the World Food Program and the UN to set up operations. In fact, they were grateful that our aircraft were available to move food and supplies around. An Australian pharmacist made a major contribution to health care through the establishment of an emergency pharmaceuticals procurement and supply distribution network. The model used is likely to be adopted broadly in Indonesia for pharmaceutical supply. Working through Australian and international non-government organisations, Australian aid was the first to be distributed by boat to the outlying islands and remote areas on the devastated west coast of Aceh. Recognising the critical role of schools in returning communities to a normal state of affairs after the disaster, Australia has worked closely with UNICEF to make available basic materials-pencils, paper and text books-for primary school students in both state and Islamic schools in Aceh. Over 30 AusAIDfunded staff have been deployed to Aceh and Sri Lanka to monitor the humanitarian response and to ensure that funds provided reach the intended beneficiaries. In the Treasurer's remarks he outlined the enormous generosity of the Australian people and of the Australian business community. I have seen some of that working to make a remarkable contribution where World Vision Australia is funding the endeavours of the World Vision Foundation of Thailand in areas north of the tourist zone of Phuket, where they are seeking to provide temporary housing, to restore the fishing fleet and to bring in ties. expertise to help rebuild those communities. They are apocalyptic when you see them first hand and the task ahead is enormous. The Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 relates to the AustraliaIndonesia partnership for reconstruction and development and this bill reflects the enormous contribution Australia has made and the leading role it is playing in the international relief effort. Indonesia is the country most severely affected by the tsunami. Indonesia has warmly welcomed our efforts. During the Prime Minister's visit to Jakarta in early January, Indonesian ministers were generous in their praise of Australia. In the work I have done leading delegations on behalf of our country since, the international community has been very, very full in its praise and its recognition of the role Australia and its people have played. Indonesia's President Yudhoyono said he would never forget Australia's role. Nearly 2½ months after the tsunami, Indonesia's assistance needs are changing from immediate emergency relief to longer term reconstruction efforts. It is difficult to put into words, and therefore to put a price on, Aceh's needs. Indeed, regardless of physical reconstruction-that is, re-establishing the hardware of those communities-the human cost will endure. The software has taken a battering, and it remains still beyond comprehension that so many were lost to their families, their communities and their countries. It has been estimated that half the population of Banda Aceh has lost its life as a result of this disaster. In some places it is difficult to comprehend that communities even existed. These are landscapes which are apocalyptic and lunar in their characteristics today but which just prior to Boxing Day were vibrant, energetic and happy communiBut an important part of an eventual healing will be the reconstruction of the tsunami devastated parts of northern Sumatra, particularly in Aceh. Together, the Indonesian government and international community have been working to estimate the cost of reconstruction in tsunami-affected areas in Indonesia-arriving at a figure in the billions of dollars. The Indonesian government is well advanced on developing an Aceh reconstruction plan, which is scheduled to be released in mid March. Indonesia will need the world's help, and Australia will have an important role to play. On 5 January, 10 days after the tsunami, Prime Minister Howard and President Yudhoyono agreed to a major new bilateral program, the $1 billion Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development. The partnership presents an historic opportunity to assist Indonesia's recovery from the devastating loss of life and the economic damage inflicted by the tsunami. In addressing Indonesia's reconstruction and development needs, it will also serve to our countries and our peoples closer together. The Australian government has decided to contribute $500 million in grants and a further $500 million in loans to the partnership over the next five years. The partnership is Australia's largest single aid program. These funds will be additional to Australia's existing development cooperation program and will bring Australia's commitment to Indonesia to a total of $1.8 billion over the next five years. Many people might not be aware that this year there is approximately $161 million of aid and development assistance work being provided by Australia to Indonesia. That bilateral development cooperation program aims at strengthening economic and financial management, building the institutions of democracy, promoting stability and security, and improving the quality and accessibility of government services. Australia's counterterrorism capacity building initiative for Indonesian police, financial intelligence and border control agencies is also continuing. There has been a boost in funding for improvements in access to education, including a new learning assistance program for Islamic schools. We are also expanding our program of assistance in the area of HIVAIDS prevention and treatment as well as building capacity, in partnership with the Indonesian authorities and their people, in communicable disease surveillance and control. So it would be wrong to characterise our constructive, welcomed and meaningful engagement at a development assistance level as not being something long established. We have those networks and there has been good work going on. This remarkable package represents a very substantial upscaling in that already positive engagement. The Prime Minister and the Indonesian President will jointly oversee the implementation of the Australia-Indonesia Partnership bring for Reconstruction and Development, with advice and assistance from a joint commission comprising the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Treasurer and two Indonesian ministers. The first meeting of the joint commission will take place in ever Canberra on 17 March. The partnership will support Indonesia's reconstruction and development efforts, both in Aceh and beyond. An important part of the partnership's activities will be focusing on practical efforts to rebuild physical structures, such as buildings and infrastructure. But reconstruction will require much more than bricks and mortar. Given the horrendous loss of life in Acehincluding doctors, nurses, policemen and government workers-rebuilding human capital will be equally important. As the details of the program are developed and worked through in partnership with Indonesians, a number of areas of interest are emerging, such as: support for income genthe eration and having people get back to their livelihoods; education and child welfare; water and waste management; health and human services; disaster preparedness; and governance, making sure the civil architecture is there to support vibrant and forwardlooking communities. The partnership's focus will not be restricted to just Aceh or reconstruction; the partnership provides us with an opportunity to make a major contribution to Indonesia's own reform goals and to contribute to a stable and prosperous society. It is a strategic commitment to support the new Indonesian government in its efforts to raise the living standards of the people of Indonesia. Through grants offered under the partnership, we hope that communities will be able to quickly rebuild and re-establish local infrastructure destroyed or damaged by the disaster, as well as participate in education and training opportunities. The concessional financing provided through the partnership is aimed at reconstruction, including the rehabilitation of major infrastructure. We are awaiting the finalisation of Indonesia's reconstruction plan for Aceh. This planning document will be critical in guiding programming decisions by Australia and other donors. We also have two officers seconded to Bakornas, Indonesia's official aid coordination agency. They will work with their Indonesian colleagues to determine exactly what projects will be recommended to the joint commission. Australia continues to be a firm supporter of increased harmonisation of donor programs and we will continue to work with other donors to ensure that reconstruction efforts in Aceh and elsewhere in the region are well coordinated, effective and accountable. The AIPRD's joint commission will consider a range of assistance proposals over the next five years. It will be guided by Indonesia's own assessment of its reconstruction and development needs, as well as our common experience as long standing development cooperation partners, which I alluded to earlier. Funding under the program will be available to help Indonesia advance its reform program. President Yudhoyono has outlined an ambitious reform program, includjust ing reform in the areas of economic governance and public sector management-where Australia has relevant expertise. More effective and efficient governance has the potential to provide a significant benefit to all Indonesians, including those affected by the tsunami. Funding will also be available under the partnership to support Indonesia's economic and social development plans outside Aceh-for example, to improve health and education outcomes. These appropriation bills are an important step in implementing the agreement between the Prime Minister and President Yudhoyono to establish the partnership. The government will be working hard over the coming months and years to ensure that Australia's reconstruction and development assistance is delivered effectively and promptly. At the same time, we recognise that we have a clear duty to ensure that the partnership spends money in a transparent and accountable manner. The Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development, though born of tragic circumstances, is an opportunity for Australia to contribute to Indonesia's reconstruction and development for the future. I also believe it is an opportunity for our nation to forge an even stronger relationship with Indonesia for the future. I commend these bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: The Labor Party welcomes Australia's commitment of $1 billion over five years to the Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development as announced by the Prime Minister on 5 January. On the morning of Sunday, 26 December a severe earthquake in the ocean off the coast of northern Sumatra caused tidal waves that devastated communities in neighbouring countries and other countries in the Indian Ocean. The earthquake measured nine on the Richter scale, the world's most severe earthquake in 40 years. The tsunamis resulted in a disaster of extraordinary proportions. The death toll is now put at more than 225,000. The casualty list continues to grow and it is acknowledged that an exact death toll will never be known. The UN estimates that the tsunamis displaced one million people and deprived five million people of basic services. The human cost of the disaster is clearly beyond measurement. But this tragedy has galvanized the humanitarian spirit around the world and in Indonesia. Whilst it is impossible to replace the losses from this truly horrific event, the government of Indonesia, with the support of the international community, is taking on the important task of reconstruction. Ultimately this task is less about replacing physical sets than it is about rebuilding livelihoods and communities. This can only happen by developing a credible recovery plan, relying on an approach that truly captures the aspirations and the vision of the people of Aceh and northern Sumatra. As the needs shift from immediate relief to longer term recovery, we do need a coherent, credible and comprehensive strategy that addresses the considerable challenges raised by the scope of the disaster. As we know, Indonesia bore the brunt of the disaster, concentrated in the provinces of Aceh and north Sumatra. Hundreds of communities have been washed away, local governments have collapsed and, in many cities and villages, the tsunamis painted a line of destruction across the landscape. On one side of the line, nearly all the infrastructure must be rebuilt or rehabilitated. But the wounds on the other side are devastating as well, as the people of Aceh and north Sumatra have been severely traumatised by the scale of the tragedy. Rebuilding the region will require far more than rebuilding roads and bridges; it will entail reviving lives, livelihoods and resurrecting entire communities. The government of Indonesia's response to the immediate needs of relief efforts has been swift and effective. As this critical work makes the transition to reconstruction and communities begin to recover from the initial shock and face the future, we need a comprehensive strategy to guide the reconstruction process. These bills pave the way for that partnership and lay the groundwork for a closer and more cooperative relationship between Australia and Indonesia. The Asian Development Bank reports that houses, boats, ports, hotels, clinics, roads, railways, fishing boats, shops, vehicles, businesses and so on were lost, and this is obvious to everyone who has viewed the tragedy on television. You could see the tremendous impact as- on local communities. That is why we have a very big challenge ahead of us. We have been faced with human loss on an unprecedented scale, but it is not just that. How do we minimise the economic impact, particularly, on these communities and help them to rebuild their livelihoods and their businesses? The direct economic impact of the events of 26 December will come through in negative effects on consumption and business activity in the areas affected. The disaster, however, has not had a substantial impact on financial markets; much less, it has not led to financial or economic crisis. Standard and Poor's has already announced that, despite the extensive property damage and loss of life, sovereign credit ratings of Asian countries affected will not be modified. So far, the currencies of the affected countries have remained stable and the financial markets have been calm. The tsunami has not yet had an adverse effect on stock markets. The two sectors most affected by the events of 26 December 2004 are tourism and fishing. Reconstruction after natural disasters requires new investment that should have a positive impact, and investment should translate into jobs. The aid process has already increased demand for a range of domestic goods and services, including food, water, medicines, building materials and clothing, as well as transport and communication services. At a macroeconomic level, evidence of growing institutional commitment to and investment in disaster risk reduction is growing. Among the international financial institutions, the Hazard Management Unit of the World Bank has been instrumental in raising the visibility of investment in the disaster risk region. The overwhelming response of Australians is demonstrated by donations in excess of $A260 million, and thousands have volunteered their time, expertise and skills. lia was among the first of many nations to offer humanitarian aid, providing medical and pharmaceutical assistance, food and water, and professional assistance. A tremendous contribution was made by the Australian Defence Force, the Australian Federal Police and many government departments, and, of course, a wonderful role was played by Australian non-government aid agencies, including trade unions. Attention is now shifting to the mediumterm reconstruction of the affected region, with the opportunity to further strengthen the strategic relationship within the region, in particular bilateral relations with Indonesia. Multilateral organisations and industrialised nations have a significant role to play by working with the ravaged nations and ‘deploying a cohesive and coordinated coalition ... to assist the affected'. Austrade will be holding a series of tsunami reconstruction workshops around Australia, profiling regional experts from the World Bank, Washington; the Asian Development Bank, Manila; and AusAID, in conjunction with Austrade's senior trade commissioners for New Delhi and Jakarta. The seminars will provide participants with a detailed understanding of the progress of reconstruction planning, how funds are being disbursed and likely arrangements for contract tendering and identifying which agencies will take the lead in coordinating projects. The workshops will also provide advice to participants wanting information on ongoing procurement programs operated by multilateral development agencies. Australia has the opportunity to work with multilateral organisations and governments on three key outputs: a damage and loss assessment; a reconstruction and recovery strategy; and a recovery financing, management and governance strategy. Australia should support efforts to develop a better sense of voluntary and official flows and Austrahow these may be managed. To manage the recovery effort, the government needs to establish some general principles: maximize the use of on-budget financing; develop an effective governance framework; phase out central government support as regional governments recover capacity; and maximize grant financing, then soft loans as needed depending on fiscal and balance of payment needs. The magnitude of the disaster and its impact on multiple countries and conflict-affected regions also presents special challenges for financing reconstruction and for aid coordination. Particular issues include: ensuring strong country ownership of reconstruction and commitment to implementation; making the transition from emergency relief to reconstruction seamless and efficient; channelling funds efficiently and transparently; providing for an equitable distribution of reconstruction activities; and ensuring that funds are put to their intended use. But the most important priority in the transition from relief to reconstruction is to put money into the pockets of those people left without a source of income-for example, through ‘cash for work' programs. Paying people for participating in the immediate clean-up after the disaster puts cash in the hands of families and helps people rebuild their lives. Giving people back some selfsufficiency and coordinating assistance to small-scale activities has implications for how efficiently we provide support. There are lessons from elsewhere that show the advantages of cash for work and communitydriven development programs that build upon the knowledge and resources of the community. Credit and microfinance is important. As commercial banks re-establish operations, the demand from SMEs and large firms for new credit to rebuild and purchase working capital will be high. A credit facility through commercial banks to business should be established to promote investment and accelerate rebuilding. A large number of small businesses which may not have access to the formal banking sector will try to access credit through non-commercial bank sources such as a framework for recovery and reconstruction cooperatives, credit unions, development banks and microfinance institutions. Smaller business credit programs should be channelled through these organisations. We need to rehabilitate transport infrastructure. The reconstruction program needs to restore the structural integrity of heavily damaged or destroyed roads, ports and airports. This could include new construction where this would improve the resilience of the transport network against disasters and improve the capacity for future growth. The reconstruction work should include upgrading of construction standards where necessary to ensure capacity, loadings and resilience of structures. Employment-intensive investment in infrastructure is also needed. In the rehabilitabe tion phase, the main priority is to focus on infrastructure that is fundamental to improving access to markets which provide productive inputs and basic living necessities. Labour based methods should be used to the extent that is economically and technically feasible. The infrastructure should therefore be both asset creating and employment creating. We need to encourage entrepreneurship. In parallel with a local economic revival strategy, we should focus on local entrepreneurship and the promotion of micro and small enterprises, enhancing their capacity to respond to emerging opportunities and new initiatives. During the rehabilitation phase many people will turn to microenterprise activities to generate income. These emerging entrepreneurs will need access to microfinance and know-how. Special attention must be given to women entrepreneurs, as they commonly constitute the largest number of microentrepreneurs yet are the most disadvantaged in terms of access to productive resources. Trust funds are a proven instrument for channelling funds to priority areas, lowering the costs of administration in both recipient and donor countries and simplifying reporting and oversight. Trust fund oversight can only be done by a committee of multilateral institutions that will ensure equitable distribution of trust fund resources. The Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund has been cited as an example of how such a trust fund might be organised. The World Bank is having discussions with several countries and donors about establishing multidonor trust funds that will finance the next phase of recovery. In all of this, ensuring accountability and transparency is essential to maintaining the confidence of both affected communities and donor country governments, who must accountable to their taxpayers. Again there are established models for making information on the sources and uses of funds available to those receiving services and for contracting out auditing, financial management and procurement to outside firms. The tsunami disaster should be seen in the context of other disasters that have hit Asia. Historically, Asia has been subjected to regular, unexpected shocks. The developing countries of Asia have always responded swiftly and pragmatically. Resilience in the face of turbulence has characterised Asia. Sound macroeconomic management, particularly fiscal discipline, has been fundamental in providing governments with the needed degrees of freedom to respond. At the microeconomic level, the availability of appropriate institutions, incentives and infrastructure is a precondition for recovery. The impressive improvements in both macreconomic and microeconomic fundamentals will make developing Asia increasingly resilient. Australia, through this program, the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005, has a critical role to play in ensuring that this aid package is delivered in an effective, transparent and sustained manner.

Speaker: Mrs MAY
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: MCPherson) (11.33 a.m.)There is not a member of this House or, indeed, any Australian who was not affected and moved by the devastating coverage of the Boxing Day tsunami disaster on our television screens. There was the enormity of the loss of life-more than 290,000 people lost their lives, including, sadly, 21 confirmed Australians; the complete devastation of homes and entire villages; the heartwrenching stories of human courage; and the miracles we witnessed over the first week or so after the tsunami hit. Sitting in our lounge rooms, it was hard to comprehend the enormous destruction and the long road that lay ahead in rebuilding those communities, spread across a number of countries from Indonesia to South Africa, which were destroyed in some way by this natural disaster. Australia was there on the ground first. Our government realised very quickly what was going to be needed, announcing a $60 million package of emergency assistance to address the immediate needs. Our aid agencies went into action immediately and Australians responded magnificently, with unprecedented fundraising of more than $280 million. The overwhelming generosity of Australians was magnificent and to this day that fundraising continues. On the Gold Coast, our local communities responded very quickly and I was delighted to be involved in a number of fundraising events, including the tsunami concert at the Royal Pines Resort that was put together by Normie Rowe and a great bunch of volunteers. The legislation before the House today commits Australia to ongoing support and aid to Indonesia, particularly to communities in Aceh and to the city of Banda Aceh-a troubled area of Indonesia but undoubtedly the area that suffered the most from the tsunami disaster. The immediate problems of providing clean water, shelter and food, stemming the real danger of disease breaking out and restoring services and infrastructure were enormous tasks undertaken by Australian Defence Force personnel. ADF engineers were on the ground in Banda Aceh to help restore these services and the infrastructure within days after the tsunami disaster struck. Australian Army and Royal Australian Air Force personnel established a water purification plant to produce 480,000 litres of clean water for the Indonesian province. Members of the Combat Engineer Regiment in the Northern Territory were deployed to Banda Aceh on HMAS Kanimbla. Their tasks were to assist with road construction and repair, airfield construction and repair, general infrastructure repair and recovery, more water purification, removal of debris, the distribution of supplies, the creation of centres for displaced persons and other identified tasks for the Indonesian people. The group took a large quantity of heavy plant equipment, including trucks, bulldozers, excavators, rollers and other engineering equipment, which has assisted with the removal of debris, the clearance of roads, the removal of partly demolished buildings and the clearance of rubbish. This is but a small sample of the tasks that had to be undertaken and will continue to be undertaken over months and possibly years in an effort to rebuild the Aceh province. The Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005 will ensure ongoing Australian support to Indonesia in the wake of the tsunami disaster. There are two main elements to the funding included in the bills, including supplementary funding for departments and agencies for their involvement in the immediate response to the tsunami disaster and the $1 billion associated with the AustraliaIndonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development Program. The AIPRD will assist with post-tsunami reconstruction as well as reinforcing the increasingly close relationover ship between our two countries. For example, Indonesia is included in Australia's top 10 trading partners, both for exports and imports. Similarly, Australia is included in donesia's top 10 trading partners, also both for exports and imports. In order to manage such a large commitment effectively, the $1 billion will be appropriated to two special accounts created under the Financial Management and Accountability Act. By using special accounts, the funds will be separated from other aid money and can only be spent on the purposes for which they have been established. The AIPRD also ensures a high degree of transparency and accountability. One special account will provide $500 million in grant aid. The other will provide loans for the reconstruction and rehabilitation of major infrastructure. The loans will involve up to $500 million in interest free financing for up to 40 years, with no repayment of principal commencing before 10 years. The partnership will support Indonesia's post-tsunami reconstruction and development efforts. Its approach will be long-term cooperation focused on economic and social development projects and Indonesian programs for reform and democratisation. The supplementary funding for emergency assistance is $131.4 million to fund the disaster response activities of Australian agencies in the weeks and months immediately following the tsunami. AusAID will receive $50.6 million for projects which include a civilian hospital in Banda Aceh, which performed 20 to 30 operations a day and treated hundreds of other patients with serious medical conditions such as severe lung infections, the supply of five medical teams to Indonesia and one medical team each to Sri Lanka and the Maldives, the delivery of four tonnes of medical supplies and eight tonnes of medical equipment to Sri Lanka, valued at $1 million, the delivery of 2.5 million litres of water to Banda Aceh, and the establishment of a medium-term civil medical team at Banda Aceh's general hospital and In- the commencement of rapid master planning exercises for the Banda Aceh health and medical sectors. The Department of Defence has been allocated $50.5 million for key defence activities during the emergency, including running a 90-bed hospital in Banda Aceh, producing 4.7 million litres of clean water with water purification plants, and clearing 7,000 cubic meters of debris. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade requires $17.3 million to cover costs associated with providing consular assistance to Australians in the affected areas. The Disaster Victim Identification Process involved repatriating Australian remains and handling the return of personal effects. The Australian Federal Police, who were involved in the Disaster Victim Identification Process, will receive $4.9 million. The Department of Health and Aging and the Department of Family and Community Services will each receive $2.5 million and $2.4 million respectively, having responsibility for a package which includes health and psychological care for Australians injured in the tsunami, psychological care for Australians who are relatives of anyone who was injured or deceased in the tsunami and funding to help meet the transport, accommodation and funeral costs for those injured in the tsunami and the next of kin of the deceased. A number of other agencies are to receive a total of approximately $1.4 million. They are the Attorney-General's Department, CrimTrac, the Health Insurance Commission and the National Blood Authority. The areas of assistance covered by this appropriation legislation certainly demonstrate the level of emergency assistance that Indonesia needs to assist the people of Indonesia to rebuild their lives, be ongoing. I am proud that the Howard government has recognised the enormity of the need and responded appropriately. This is the largest single aid contribution in Australia's history. The magnitude of Australia's response is entirely appropriate, given the scale of the tragedy, its impact on the people of our region and the important long-term ties between Australia and its neighbours. The scale of the response was made possible as a result of the government's strong fiscal position. To all those Australians who are working on the ground, and who will continue to work for many years to come in helping to rebuild Indonesia and the Aceh province, we wish you well in the enormous task that lies ahead. Our thoughts are with you as you undertake the rebuilding of those communities affected by the tsunami. We all hope that our help, and the provision that has been made through the bill, will continue, that the rebuilding will continue and that we will see a positive outcome in the future. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: Of course, I support the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and cognate bill, the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005, as I think all members of the House would. This was, perhaps, the most tragic natural disaster of our time. It was also a catalyst for an outpouring of sympathy and support and national unity. The response of our nation was unprecedented for an event that occurred overseas. Perhaps it was because it occurred at Christmas time, or perhaps because so many Australians had been to the affected areas, like Thailand, or Indonesia or Sri Lanka. Perhaps it was because we are an island with so much of our population living on the coast and it was brought home to us how easily this could and that need will happen to us. The figures tell a devastating story. In Indonesia alone, 124,000 people have been confirmed dead. Another 111,000 are missing and likely to be deceased. While the reduction in Indonesia's gross domestic product is estimated at just 0.1 to 0.4 per cent, a more startling figure is the estimated reduction in Banda Aceh's gross domestic product, which is 97 per cent. Perhaps one of the most chilling statistics of all is that an estimated 35,000 children have been orphaned in this tragic event. The government's commendable response has been matched by an outpouring of private generosity. There were dinners, cricket matches and afternoon teas and we saw pensioners and young children donating perhaps small amounts of money, but a large percentage of their savings, to various appeals. Like many members, I had an appeal box in my electorate office. I know that some young people came in and left small amounts of money which were big contributions for them. At the other end of the scale, I was pleased to be able to attend function-organised by the Italian Affair Committee, which is a big charity group in my electorate-which raised $1,000,000 for the tsunami appeal. I congratulate the Chairman of the Italian Affair Committee, Pat Sergei OAM-a person who has been congratulated in this House before for his other works-for his role and the role of his organising committee. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Brand, was able to join us at that function. The target of $1,000,000 was helped to be reached by a very generous donation from Sergeants Pies of $500,000, which, from a single organisation, is a major contribution. I would like Hansard to record the House's recognition of the contribution from Sergeants Pies. This outpouring of generosity and contributions is an endorsement of the government's generous donation to the appeal. The government's response is an example of our support for our neighbours. Indonesia and Australia have, from time to time, had issues and disagreements. We have been through a very difficult period with the Bali bombing and the bombing of the Australian Embassy in Indonesia. But, at the end of the day, we are neighbours and friends and our contribution recognises this. Such generosity also provides us with an opportunity to engage the public in a debate about foreign aid generally-about our support for those less welloff, about our role in this part of the world and about our role in the world generally. I saw a study recently, which was conducted in the United States. It asked members of the public what percentage of gross domestic product they thought was spent on foreign aid. Then they were asked what percentage they thought should be spent on foreign aid. It was a very interesting survey. The results showed that the average American thought that about 15 per cent of gross domestic a product was probably spent on foreign aid and that only five per cent should be spent on foreign aid. Of course, in the case of the United States, I think the real figure is 0.5 per cent of GDP or something in that order. There is a wide misunderstanding and Americans are not alone in it. If you conducted that survey in Australia. I think you would find a very similar response and a wide misunderstanding of our role and the amounts we spend on foreign aid. If you have a survey showing that five per cent of GDP is regarded as an appropriate contribution to foreign aid then we certainly have an opportunity to do more. I read a report recently which said that $4 billion spent around the world by major developed countries could eliminate child poverty and child starvation in five to 10 years. When you consider that we pledged $1 billion to this appeal, $4 billion across the world should not be too much of an ask or contribution for the developed economies of the world to make. In supporting this bill it is important that we also engage the public in that debate and point out the benefits to the people who receive this money-the orphaned children, the families of those deceased and people trying to re-establish their microbusinessesas opposed to small businesses-their fishing boats and their small stalls in Banda Aceh, Sri Lanka, Thailand and everywhere else that has been affected. We need to encourage that spirit of entrepreneurship and help them build their infrastructure and rebuild their lives. Just as importantly, we need to engage in that debate and point out that Australia also gets benefits from foreign aid. I am not talking about economic benefits. I am not talking about goods and services being bought from Australian producers, although of course that happens. I am talking about the reputation of Australia as a caring nation which is prepared, to use an Australian vernacular expression, to help out its matescountries going through tough times or disasters, whether they be natural or human inspired. We have shown that through so many disasters-from September 11 in the United States to this tragic natural disaster in the Pacific. More than any words, conferences or dialogue, that sends a very strong message that we are prepared to put political, religious and philosophical differences aside and help people who are going through difficult times. We have seen not only an outpouring of money from the federal government and private individuals and organisations but also outpouring of effort and commitment from some very dedicated people who have travelled around the world in the most difficult of circumstances. I saw one young Australian-I think she was from Melbourne-who volunteered for the job of going through all the corpses lined up in Banda Aceh and helping families to identify them. To in some way alleviate their pain she did most of the work checking the bodies, and they just checked the ones that she identified as possiwhat's bly being their relatives. That is a job I do not think many of us could comprehend doing, but she volunteered. I think she was a medical student who happened to be in Banda Aceh at the time. That really shows the Australian spirit of helping out, which another symbol of the contribution that we have made after this terrible tragedy. We have seen Australian soldiers, police men and women from the various states, and various community aid organisations all volunteering to go and work in the most difficult circumstances imaginable, to do what they can to help in this tragedy, which, as I said, was the worse natural disaster of our time. I think it is also another chance to reassess what more we can do. I support this bill wholeheartedly as I am sure the whole House will. This is a time of national unity, a time for us all to come together and congratulate the government on its efforts. But we can do better. I support the calls from the honourable member for Griffith, the shadow minister for foreign affairs, for the government to re-examine the need to boost resources for Radio Australia. I think the decision to cut funding for Radio Australia taken early in the government's term was one of the more unfortunate cuts. The ability to broadcast was greatly reduced and the ability to engage with people in South-East Asia was emasculated to a degree which I am not sure the government really intended. I know the govan ernment has funded Radio Australia more fully in recent years than it has in the past, and I congratulate it on that, but we still need to go further. Radio Australia needs to be returned to the vibrant service that it once was. It was not a mechanism for propaganda or proselytising the Australian point of view; it was a mechanism of understanding and of saying to people of South-East Asia: ‘Here is where we're coming from on all these issues. Here is happening in Australia.' We really cannot blame people in South-East Asia for misunderstanding us if we have not made the effort to communicate our point of view to them. I understand that in 1996 and 1997 South-East Asia and Radio Australia may not is have been such high priorities as they are today. But we all recognise now, with the difficulties between Indonesia and Australia and other nations, the need to engage in that communication. I add to the calls to the government to re-examine the funding of Radio Australia and to boost that funding as much as possible. In conclusion, many of us have been to the areas which have subsequently been affected by the tsunami, and many of us will return. I spent some time in Sri Lanka. I carefully examined the maps of the devastation to see if the area I had been to had been affected, and it had been. It was brought home to me that many of the children I met in Sri Lanka and many of their parents have now probably passed away. I remember the Sri Lankan people that I stayed with as being the most friendly and open-hearted people that you could ever hope to meet. It is a personal note for me that many of them have now probably-I have no way of ascertaining-passed away. I am sure many Australians are in a similar situation. For those who have spent time in Phuket, Sri Lanka, the east coast of India or Indonesia, many of the people they have holidayed with, stayed with and come to know as friends have been killed in this terrible tragedy. That is, as I said in my opening remarks, perhaps a reason that Australians have responded so generously to this event which really, coming so closely after Christmas, shook us to our core and shook us into a realisation that at the end of the day, despite any political, religious or philosophical differences, we are all citizens of the world and we must all come together in these times of crisis. I commend the bill to the House. I congratulate the government on its initiative and on its generous and quick response. I join with the other members of the opposition in supporting this bill and moving forward to the next stage of reconstruction, which is going to be very difficult. Money itself will not achieve this. It will take effort and a sive logistical operation to procure the raw resources for the reconstruction of housing, small businesses, hospitals et cetera. We will be with the government as it attempts that. We will support that in any way possible and we will continue to support the government and the Australian people for the efforts they have made in the face of this disaster.

Speaker: Mr BAIRD
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: It is my pleasure to follow the member for Prospect and agree with the sentiments that he has uttered today in his support for the government's Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and cognate bill, the reconstruction program that will be going on in Indonesia and the reason for this bill coming before the House. I think all of us in this country in the last few years have been stunned by the various developmentsSeptember 11, the Bali bombing and now the tsunami impact, which is, in terms of natural disasters, the most significant the world has seen. Many people until Boxing Day were not familiar with the term ‘tsunami'. Certainly its implication has been widespread. The devastation of its impact on our neighbours-particularly Indonesia and the Banda Aceh area and through into Thailand and Phuket, Sri Lanka and India-was significant. The results were appalling and tragic. The separation of families, the loss of loved ones and the fact that thousands of young people remain orphans in this area of the world are significant concerns. The great plus in Australia was the incredible response that we had across all levels of the community. In every area the response was an outpouring of support to our brothers and sisters in these other countries. As the member for Prospect has said, the way in which people have put aside their cultural and religious differences and nationalities, and come together as part of the masworld community to support those affected at this time, is unique. We are sending out in a very significant way members of the government to assist in the clean-up efforts. Members of the defence forces, the Australian Federal Police and medical teams undertook magnificent work. It was heart warming to see the Australians out there responding so well, being involved at the heart of the action. Some of their work was quite tragic, identifying the bodies that have been recovered; some were in teams involved in amputations. I have talked to a group of orthopaedic surgeons. The extent of the devastation on people and the number of amputees that will be around, particularly in Indonesia, will be very significant. The level of aid that has been given across the world has also been very encouraging. I know in my own community that the response was particularly encouraging. Immediately, committees were formed to raise funds. Mr Glen Wheeler, who was previously with radio 2GB, headed up a committee that raised almost $100,000. Some of the leading people in our community were caught up in it. Les Boardman and his wife, Diane, were in Phuket at the time of the tsunami and were caught up in the waves and swept underneath. Mrs Boardman, who was trapped underneath a car, explained to me how horrific it was-she thought that she would die, then suddenly the car was lifted by another wave coming through. She told me first-hand what the experience was like. We will never quite appreciate the number of people who lost their lives in this experience and the number of families who were so devastated by the impact. The numbers are so significant. It was the earth's worse natural disaster in living memory. The current death toll is expected to be in excess of 273,000 people. The Indonesian government alone revised its official death toll to firmed dead and 94,574 missing. We will undoubtedly never know the full impact of this tragedy. So it is our response to this tragedy that is most important. In my area, even tomorrow night we are having yet another fund raiser. We have had previous ones. All of the key restaurants in Cronulla had a special day when all the proceeds from that day went to the recovery work in Banda Aceh. All of the staff gave their time as well. The product was given freely by the seafood merchants in the area. It was great to see the community coming together, including even the local pub. I went to receive a cheque on behalf of World Vision for $60,000 from people down at the pub who gave to this appeal. Tomorrow night Qantas are giving free air travel to Hong Kong for the golf club which is holding a major fundraiser in my area. The purpose of this bill is particularly aimed at the very significant gift that has been given to the reconstruction in Indonesia. Banda Aceh was the worse affected of the tsunami devastated areas. It had the most significant death toll. That is where we will be targeting our aid. We gave in the order of $1 billion. It was a significant amount. It was saying to our closest neighbour: ‘We stand here with you. We realise the trauma you have been through. We understand the need for reconstruction of the country and we want to support you at this time.' The response of the new President of Indonesia was heart warming, as was seeing the way in which the two countries can work together for such an important good. These bills will see not only $500 million in direct grants but $500 million in interest free loans, which is significant. They will start to be repaid in 10 years time. It is most significant. On a pragmatic level, undoubtedly that will lead to opportunities for Australian and Indonesian companies to bid for and participate in re125,598 con- construction activities. This aid package is the largest single aid contribution in Australia's history. It is important that we ensure a smooth delivery of this assistance. I heard the member for Prospect expressing concern about the level of aid. This certainly shows that we are going to be right up there. It is the largest amount of aid given by any country and it is significant. The bill includes two main elements for funding. Part 1 looks at the supplementary funding for departments and agencies that are currently involved in the region and those that were involved in the immediate response to the disaster. The other part contains the billion that the government has pledged for the Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development. In delivering this very large aid package, the bill builds the very strong economy that we have in Australia. Because of the good management of the Australian economy, we have a strong financial base-we have had growth averaging 3.5 per cent over the past 14 years. On that strong base we have been very blessed and very fortunate in this country. As a result of that good fortune Australia is in a position to provide this aid. The fund will assist with post tsunami reconstruction. It will also provide a platform to strengthen our relationship with Indonesia and enhance our regional partnership. That is so important for a country of 180 million people and our closest neighbour. It is important that we develop that relationship. Indonesia is already one of Australia's top 10 trading partners and vice versa. The package will foster an already large and growing trend of trade between our countries. Since this commitment is so large, under the Financial Management and Accountability Act the government will appropriate $1 billion in two accounts. This will ensure greater accountability and transparency in tracking the aid payments and allocation to ensure that they are allocated for the reason they were given in the first place. There will be one account that provides the $500 million in grant aid and then the interest free loans will be financed up to 40 years with principal repayments after 10 years. Supplementary funding of an additional $131 million is being sought to top up the agencies and departments that responded to the crisis immediately following the tragic event. AusAID, the Department of Defence, DFAT, the Federal Police and the Department of Health and Ageing have all been involved. AusAID, for example, set up a ci$1 vilian hospital in Banda Aceh, carrying out surgical operations 20 to 30 times a day as well as treating hundreds of walk-in patients with serious complications ranging from on lung infections to gangrene. They also supplied five specialist medical teams to Indonesia and one each to Sri Lanka and the Maldives. Over four tonnes of medical supplies have been provided to Sri Lanka along with eight tonnes of medical equipment, all valued at more than $1 million. In addition, 2.5 million litres of water have been provided to Banda Aceh. A medium-term civil medical unit has been established at the general hospital, and training and exercises have been carried out for rapid master planning in the health and medical sectors. Some $50.6 million has been allocated for AusAID's contribution. The Department of Defence has been allocated $50.5 million for its activities, ranging from running a 90-bed hospital in Aceh, producing 4.7 million litres of purified, clean water and the clearing of 7,000 cubic metres of debris. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will be provided with $17.3 million to cover the costs of providing consular assistance and victim identification, and repatriating the remains of Australians and returning victims' personal effects. The Federal Police, who were instrumental in the identification of victims, will be provided with $4.9 million to cover costs. The Department of Health and Ageing will receive $2.5 million and the Department of Family and Community Services will receive $2.4 million to cover the cost of their packages, which provided for health and psychological care for Australians injured in the tsunami and for the relatives of those who lost loved ones in the disaster. The Attorney-General's Department, CrimTrac, the Health Insurance Commission and the National Blood Authority will receive collectively a total of $1.4 million to cover costs. It is also important to note that many of the departments listed absorbed many of the costs into their existing budgets, which has heavily reduced the amount of supplementary funding required. The total financial implication of this bill is $1.133 billion, which in anyone's language is a very large amount of funding for a bill passing through this House. Also significant is the degree of bipartisan support for this bill, which is encouraging. We can all take pride in the fact that this country is financially strong and in a position to provide level of aid. It is a gesture towards our est neighbour, extending our feeling of solidarity in this time of need to assist them in meeting the impact of the devastation of the tsunami and helping them with the reconstruction and rebuilding of their hospitals, schools and homes. It is going to be a long and difficult path for them, but at least they will know that Australia stands with them and that we will be providing resources to assist them in this program. It is certainly a significant step forward. I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr RICHARDSON
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: I rise today in support of the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 20042005 and the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005. On 26 December 2004, while Australians recovered from Christmas Day celebrations, watched the Boxing Day test and simply enjoyed the company of family and friends, the most severe earthquake the world has seen in the last 40 years shook the ocean beds surrounding our nearest neighbours.
