The tragic tsunami that followed meant that, while Australians were enjoying and taking for granted the activities that generally entertain us on Boxing Day, our neighbours were running for their lives and fighting to save their loved ones. This Boxing Day tragedy has resulted in an unprecedented humanitarian disaster the likes of which we have not seen in this lifetime and the likes of which we hope and pray we will never see again. We will never know the true human cost of this disaster. We can never truly understand the emotional cost of having the life of a loved one cut desperately short by a natural disaster of this magnitude or the effect this disaster will have on the small, close-knit communities of the nations affected. We will never truly know the effect this it has had on a generation of children, who closwere either washed away in the disaster or left behind to face life after the loss of parents and grandparents, brothers and sisters, friends and neighbours-a generation of children who, at the hands of nature, were left orphaned. But there is something we can do and that is why I stand before the House today. I stand before the House to support a bill which aims to make a real difference in the lives and communities of those people most affected in the aftermath of the tsunami. I was motivated to speak in support of this bill not only because of the real difference it will make in the lives of so many people scattered throughout the devastated region and not only because of the undeniable merits this legislation has but also because I was inspired by the selfless acts of Australians I saw in the aftermath of the disaster, particularly by the constituents and organisations within my electorate of Kingston and throughout South Australia and nationally. The examples of the extraordinary acts of extraordinary people in my electorate are so wide and varied-from the electrician who jumped on a plane as soon as he was able to get his paperwork organised to go over and help rebuild the devastated townships, to the woman who collected clothing and travelled to Indonesia to distribute it to those Indonesians most in need. Groups of young people in my electorate organised raffles and concerts, and spent their weekends walking around at community fairs collecting donations for the relief effort. The people of Kingston, like the people of this fine nation, showed their extraordinary generosity. Now it is the Howard government's turn, on behalf of all Australians, to do the same. We doing that with the largest single aid contribution in this nation's history. There are two main elements of the funding included in these bills. The first includes supplementary funding for departments and agencies for their involvement in the immediate response to the disaster. The second is the $1 billion which is being committed for the Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development. The partnership is designed to support Indonesia's posttsunami reconstruction and development efforts with a long-term focus on economic and social development projects, as well as Indonesian programs for reform and democratisation. The first meeting between the resentatives from Australia and Indonesia is scheduled for 17 March 2005 and looms as being one of the defining moments in the modern relationship between our two nations. The supplementary funding which is being sought is for $131.4 million to fund disaster response activities of Australian agencies in the weeks and months immediately following the tsunami. The funds include $50.6 million sought by AusAID for projects which included a civilian hospital in Banda Aceh which was at the coalface of the relief effort, performing between 20 and 30 operations a day and treating hundreds of other patients with serious conditions, including those who faced serious risk from infection; the delivery of 12 tonnes of medical supplies and equipment to Sri Lanka; the supply of five medical teams to Indonesia, one medical team to Sir Lanka and another one to the Maldives; the establishment of a mediumterm civil medical team at Banda Aceh General Hospital, as well as the introduction of master planning exercises for the Banda Aceh health and medical sectors; and the delivery of 2.5 million litres of water to Banda Aceh. Funding in the amount of $50.5 are million has also been allocated to the Department of Defence. The activities funded include running a 90-bed hospital in Banda Aceh, clearing 7,000 cubic metres of debris and producing 4.7 million litres of clean water with purification plants. I would like to digress for a moment to talk briefly about the work of the Australian Defence Force in the region. The very dedicated men and women who join the armed forces do so with the desire and will to stand up and fight to defend our nation, but following this disaster those men and women proudly stood up, as they were shipped off to areas more devastated than a war zone, to help and assist the people of a foreign nation. rep- These soldiers knew they were not going to fight to free an oppressed people or to defend the shores of their nation, but they stood with pride in their uniforms and pride in their nation as they were shipped off to do something that would touch many lives and mark our national history just as proudly. I would like to take this opportunity to thank every member of the Australian Defence Force who has headed to the devastated regionand every husband or wife, son or daughter, mother or father who has had to endure time without their loved ones while they serve their country so honourably. We are proud of your dedication, we are proud of your commitment and we are so very proud of what you have accomplished in such a short time. These bills provide $17.3 million to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to cover costs associated with providing consular assistance to Australians in the affected areas, repatriating Australian remains and handling the return of personal effects. As well, along with the Australian Federal Police effort, the disaster victim identification process, for which $4.9 million is being provided, is supplying much needed closure to the families of victims. The Department of Health and Ageing is to receive $2.5 million, and the Department of Family and Community Services is to receive $2.4 million for a package which includes health and psychological care for Australians injured in the tsunami; psychological care for Australians who are relatives of anyone who was injured or killed in the tsunami; and funding to help meet the transport and accommodation costs of those injured in the tsunami and the next of kin of those who were killed, and funeral costs. A total of approximately $1.4 million will go to a number of other agencies, including the Attorney-General's Department, CrimTrac, the Health Insurance Commission and the National Blood Authority. None of this funding accounts for the money spent by agencies which have absorbed the costs within their existing budgets. Having outlined the details of the funding, I would like to take this opportunity to point out that the Howard government's assistance to tsunami affected countries has attracted not just broad community support but also bipartisan support. So often Australians look at the two sides of politics and wonder if ever possible for them to agree. So often in this House there are days when we, like the opposition, wonder the same thing. But today both sides of Australian politics have come together in support of this humanitarian legislation. Today we celebrate the sense of bipartisan cooperation which is enabling us to reach out to our neighbours and support them in this desperate time. I thank the opposition for their support. On a personal note, I would like to say that there is no way I can understand the feeling of losing a loved one in a disaster of this magnitude, and I pray that I will never find out. But, as the father of two boys, I was both touched and overwhelmed when a mother from the suburb of Hallett Cove in my electorate contacted my office at the height of the disaster because her son was in the area where the tsunami hit and she was unable to contact him. As this woman spoke to me on the phone about the fear she felt at not knowing if her son was alive or dead, I felt a small part of what other families who were missing loved ones at the time must have been feeling. Fortunately, that mother's son was returned to her alive and well. But when I went home that night and hugged my own wife and sons I wondered what on earth I could do, and today I can answer that question with my support of this legislation. As the Prime Minister said on the National Day of Mourning and Reflection: We know we cannot wind back the clock. We know the physical and emotional scars left by this disaster can never fully heal. We know, too, that we must not let our mourning turn to despair as we shoulder the mammoth task of helping those who have lost so much. The Prime Minister was right: we cannot change history, but we can shape the future, and we begin the process of reshaping the future of the tsunami affected areas today with the passage of this very important legisit is lation. This bill lets us reach out to our neighbours, it lets us save and rebuild lives, and it lets us continue our fight to ensure that the people devastated by this tragedy are not forgotten. Through this tragedy and Australia's support of the devastated region, we have forged a stronger, more secure relationship with our neighbours. Our Defence Force and civil personnel engaged in the relief effort in Indonesia, for example, are working with and alongside their Indonesian counterparts to achieve the best and quickest possible results for the people of Indonesia. It is hard to believe that any good could come of a disaster like this, but it is impossible not to recognise the good in the heart of every Australian who dug deep to donate to the various charities collecting for the victims. Australians gave all that they could, from children giving their pocket money, to those who gave their time. Australians have again, through this disaster, rallied beyond all possible expectation to show their compassion and desire to help those in need. It is in times like these that we look for Australian heroes. During this disaster, we found them. We found them on the street corners, holding collection tins. We found them in our Defence Force personnel, in our doctors and nurses, volunteers who jumped on flights to go and lend a hand, and we found them in every Australian household which donated so selflessly to help their neighbours in need. Out of this disaster has come a reminder of the true meaning of the Australian spirit and a redefinition of Australian mateship, which now recognisably extends beyond our shores. I commend this bill to the House because it is the government's extension of that mateship. It is the means by which this government can have a real impact on the nations touched by this tragedy. I commend this bill to the House because it will make a difference.

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak on the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and related legislation. As the previous speaker indicated, this bill has bipartisan support. The opposition was clear in its support for major assistance to Indonesia before, during and after discussion first arose about the issue in the area of foreign aid generally but the tsunami in particular. This bill embodies that bipartisan consensus-and, indeed, the consensus across the country-about Australia's response to the earthquake and tsunami disaster that affected the countries of our region, particularly Indonesia, on 26 December and its aftermath during the following months. According to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, 21 Australians have now been confirmed lost in the tsunami disaster, while another six are missing, apparently lost. Although these figures are much lower than we originally feared, each one is a tragedy for an Australian family. I offer my sincere condolences to all of those affected. We can be thankful that Australia escaped with so few losses, when we reconsider that the overall death toll has now reached some 310,000. I was contacted on the first day. I went back into my office to see of what assistance I could be to citizens of Melbourne Ports who had family lost in various parts of Thailand and later Sri Lanka. I was immediately in contact with the Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Bruce Billson, who was on his mobile. We got the details to him of some missing Australians in Thailand, faxed from the mother of one of the missing young women. I must say that I was very pleased that the government acted so quickly and that the member for Dunkley, the Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs and Trade, was so accessible and so quick in acting at the request of parliamentarians on behalf of their constituents. As previous speakers have done, I want to pay tribute to all of those Australians who rallied so magnificently to bring aid and comfort to the millions of people affected by the tsunami. These include, first and foremost, the men and women of the Australian Defence Force, who acted with their usual promptness, efficiency and compassion to bring aid to the affected areas, most particuthose larly to the Aceh province in Indonesia. I think the sight of the Australians with their water bottles, giving out fresh water to ple in that devastated region, will be an age that sticks in all of our minds. That praise extends to federal and state government departments, including the Australian Federal Police; the aid organisations which sent volunteers and funds; and the many Australians who stayed in the affected areas to work as volunteers. In my own electorate, as I said, many generous people gave to various appeals. I attended a tsunami benefit at the Amici Bakery Cafe in Chapel Street, Prahran, with my colleague the state member for Prahran, Mr Tony Lupton. The cafe donated all of the fees from the benefit that night-$6,500-to the tsunami relief effort. There were many similar efforts by businesses, community groups and individuals. All the Fitzroy Street and Acland Street traders took up money on behalf of the Red Cross. The tsunami victims affected in my electorate include Robbie Burke, formerly the saxophonist of the Black Sorrows, who lives in Caulfield, his wife, Atia Cader, and their two daughters, who had a narrow escape in Sri Lanka; and, on Phi Phi Island, Leonard Hamersfeld and Tanya Bensimon of East St Kilda, who huddled behind a wall and then scrambled onto a roof to escape the waters. Australians have donated $280 million to charities assisting the tsunami affected counnesian tries, which I think is the highest per capita voluntary donation for tsunami relief of any country in the world and is certainly an extraordinary outpouring of generosity from a country of 20 million people. It follows from this that Australians expect their government to be equally generous. The total aid commitments of the Australian government to the tsunami relief total nearly $1.4 billion, and commitments have the full support of the opposition. We expect those commitments to be fully honoured, and a future Lapeo- bor government would of course honour im- those commitments, which will run for many years into the future. I want to talk today about the link between Australia's tsunami relief efforts and our relationship with Indonesia. The tsunami, coming as it did soon after the inauguration of Indonesia's first directly elected president, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, provides an opportunity for relations between Australia and our largest and most important regional neighbour to make a fresh start after the various stresses and strains of the past decade. As Indonesia is the world's largest Muslim country, our relationship with Indonesia is an extraordinarily important one, particularly in the current international climate. We have a great stake in Indonesia remaining a united, stable, democratic and increasingly prosperous country. If it does not-if it breaks up into warring provinces, if it relapses into dictatorship or succumbs to Islamist extremism or if its economic progress goes into reverse-the consequences for Australia could be immediate and severe. In the past, many people in the foreign policy establishment in this country, including members from both sides of politics, took the view that what was needed above all else in Indonesia was stability, and that Australia's interests lay in propping up the Indoauthoritarian governments and all that that entailed including, unfortunately, the Indonesian occupation of East Timor. I do not seek to make a partisan point about this, as this was the policy of successive Australian governments and was the wisdom of the time. However, Australia's support for the incorporation of East Timor not only had a morally problematic aspect to it but was also short-sighted and not in the long-term interests of either Australia or Indonesia. All authoritarian regimes eventually fall and, when they do, the people who suffered under them remember who their friends were. This lesson applies as much to Burma today as it did to Indonesia yesterday. Today we can see that Australia's interests lie in supporting and promoting Indonesian democracy as the best way of securing a stable and prosperous Indonesia into the future. We must pay tribute here to the former presidents Abdurrahman Wahid and Megawati Sukarnoputri, who both courageously opposed dictatorship and worked to create a democratic Indonesia. For various reasons neither of them proved to be effective presidents, but they paved the way for the country's first direct presidential election and election of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono last year. There is no great controversy in supporting democracy but I also believe that it is in Australia's interests to support a united Indonesia. That may be a more controversial proposition. This issue has been brought into sharper focus by the fact that the tsunami struck hardest in the Aceh province of Indonesia, where there has been a long-running secessionist insurgency. The behaviour of both the Indonesian military and the insurgent group, GAM, has been brought into focus by the unprecedented media attention given to events in Aceh since the tsunami struck. It may seem paradoxical that I should speak in support of Indonesian national unity so soon after expressing support for the independence of East Timor, and that is the position of a lot of members of both sides of this House. However, East Timor was a Portuguese colony, not part of the old Dutch East Indies, and its people never agreed to become part of Indonesia. The evidence was overwhelming that the people of East Timor always retained a sense of separate nationality and wanted to be independent. By contrast, it seems to me that Aceh, West Papua and the Moluccas were part of the Dutch East Indies, and the evidence is at least ambivalent that the majority of the peoples in those areas, as opposed to some minorities, desire separation from Indonesia. After all, Indonesia has recently held free legislative and presidential elections, and voters in these regions showed no sign of support for secession. It is of course true that the incorporation of the former Dutch New Guinea into Indonesia was done without the consent of the people of that territory. But that was more than 40 years ago and, since then, the territhe tory has been integrated into Indonesia and its population mix changed by large-scale settlement from other parts of Indonesia. Now that Indonesia is a democracy, and now that all the provinces of Indonesia have their own elected regional assemblies with considerable devolved powers, I do not think we in this parliament do the people of West Papua any service by encouraging secessionism. However, we in this parliament want to encourage our Indonesian friends to be sensitive to the regional interests of people in West Papua. The same is true of Aceh, which, although once an independent sultanate that was incorporated into the Dutch East Indies in 1871, has been an integral part of Indonesia since independence nearly 60 years ago. The recent trial of Abu Bakar Bashir has reminded Australians of the great stake we have in the future of Indonesia and of Indonesian Islam. The Minister for Foreign Affairs is now here, and I express my appreciation for a recent opportunity to be with him on a visit that he regularly makes to his isterial colleagues; a number of Australian parliamentarians were taken with the foreign minister on his visit to Jakarta. The Australian parliamentarians had extremely useful meetings with our colleagues in the Indonesian parliament, including with the Speaker, Amien Rais. We also had particularly useful meetings with the leadership of Indonesian youth organisations and Indonesian Muslim organisations, including scholars and youth leaders who were remarkably well informed about Australia. Many of them had been educated in Australia, and some had undertaken PhD studies at Flinders University. They expressed no great antagonism towards Australia, although they did have politely expressed policy differences in a number of areas. The Indonesian archipelago has been Islamic since the 16th century, but Indonesian Islam, influenced by the archipelago's Buddhist, Hindu and animist history, is very ferent from the Islam we see in Saudi Arabia. Indonesian Hanafi Islam was until recently unaffected by the drift towards Islamic extremism. Most Indonesian Muslims supported moderate Islamic organisations such as Mummadiyah or Nandlatul Ulama, and most still do. I am sure the minister has met with these organisations many times, and I and parliamentarians from both sides had the opportunity to meet with them for the first time a couple of years ago when we were in Jakarta. Today Indonesian Islam in undergoing far-reaching changes as part of a process that honourable member for Griffith has called ‘Middle-Easternisation'. As Indonesians have become better educated, they have become more aware of world events such as the conflicts in the Middle East. Indonesian youth in some of the poorer regional areas are attending madrassas and being inculcated with extremist ideology by preachers from minthe Wahabist sect, funded from Saudi Arabia. In recent years this ideology of Islamist extremism, including various dislikes of Americans, Australians and Jews, has been widely spread in Indonesia by extremist clerics such as the infamous Abu Bakar Bashir. Unfortunately, Indonesia's welcome but uneasy transformation from authoritarianism to democracy has given some of these foreign inspired Islamist groups new opportunities. Older Indonesian Muslim leaders, such as the former president Wahid, have been challenged by groups such as the Council of Indonesian Islamic Scholars (MUI) and Abu Bakar Bashir's Indonesian Mujahideen Council. When I was in Indonesia in early 2003 Australian parliamentarians met a number of moderate Indonesian Muslim youth leaders and scholars. They told me how they are fighting back against the militants and their imported ideologies, which they understand to be immensely harmful to the great difreligion of Islam and to the people of Indonesia. Australia can and should be doing everything it can to help moderate Indonesian Muslims, by providing funding for secular and moderate Islamic schools in the villages to counteract the insidious effects of this imported Wahabist ideology. I have spoken a number of times in this House about the need for Australia to do more to assist the forces of moderate Islam in Indonesia, particularly in the area of education. I agree with some of the initiatives of this government in this area, noting that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is the here. Yet I also draw attention to the comments of the honourable member for Griffith about the importance of restoring the full operation of Radio Australia's Indonesian language broadcasting as a means of countering the anti-Western influences in Indonesia. The terrible tragedy of the tsunami provides new opportunities for strengthening Australia's relationship with Indonesia, and the fact that our generous aid was so well received is something that all Australian people, including both sides of this parliament, will be very pleased about. I do anyone on this side of this House had any partisan concerns about the Australian government's great initiative towards Indonesia at the time of the tsunami; we all welcomed it. We should use that influence and goodwill to work with Indonesian civil society groups to strengthen Indonesian democracy and the forces of religious and political moderation. This will make it harder for extremist groups like JI to recruit Indonesians to terrorist ganisations and make it easier for the Indonesian police to detect and prevent terrorist planning before we experience repeats of the Bali bombing or the Australian Embassy bombing. I welcome this bill and the generous financial commitment to reconstruction that it embodies. But that financial aid must be part of a wider policy framework to strengthen the bonds of friendship between the Indonesian people and the Australian people. This is in the long-term interests of both countries.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: Flinders-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (12.40 p.m.)-In addressing the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and Australia-Indonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005 I briefly want to make two points. The first point is that these bills represent part of humanitarian response which Australia and many other nations have provided to the tragedy of 26 December. That response has really come at three levels. The first, and perhaps most important, response has been at the community level. What we have seen at the community level is an extraordinary outpouring of both common humanity and direct financial and human support. That assistance, whether it be to Sri Lanka, to Indonesia, to Thailand, to Malaysia or to other parts of the Indian Ocean region, has been of trenot think that mendous importance. The second level of the humanitarian response is direct government financial support-$1 billion is laid down in this appropriation package for the Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development and $52 million to cover those costs already incurred by AusAID. I think we owe all of those members of the Australian Defence Force, the government-led by the orPrime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs-and Australians who have assisted a great deal of thanks and recognition at a national level. The third level of the humanitarian response is the international approach. The Australian government, with the support of the Australian opposition, has played a very important role in helping to broker and bring together a common approach to overcoming the terrible tragedy and the long-term needs of Indonesia in particular, of Sri Lanka, of India and of all those other countries. The other major point I want to make in brief is about the next step forward. One of the critical factors that I see as my own role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage is what we need to do about a tsunami warning system. Under the leadership of the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian the Campbell, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, we are helping to put together a regional package which deals with three things: firstly, technical assistance-and that is something which we can quite readily achieve in identifying these tragedies as occur and in warning people; secondly, providing education as to what to do in the event of such a warning; and, thirdly, and perhaps most significantly, providing a last mile warning-how do you let a village know that a crisis is coming? How do you actually inform people on the ground? That is perhaps one of the great challenges, and we are looking at that aspect of a tsunami warning system. Very simply, these two appropriation bills represent an appropriate response to the humanitarian tragedy. They recognise the common humanity; they recognise our national responsibility; they do credit to the community and to the Australian government. I am delighted to commend the bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: It is with pleasure that I stand here to wind up this second reading debate on the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance and AustraliaIndonesia Partnership) Bill 2004-2005 and the Appropriation (Tsunami Financial Assistance) Bill 2004-2005. I want to say how much I appreciate the contributions that have been made by both government and opposition members. I listened to much of the speech of the member for Melbourne Ports and I agree with just about all of it, except his point about Radio Australia. Radio Australia does broadcast into Indonesia. I am sure where this idea that it does not came from. But it is 2005, not 1975, and people actually watch television these days. The Australian government has spent a lot of money-we spend about $19 million a year-on the ABC's Asia-Pacific TV. That has enormous reach. It goes right through Indonesia and is proving very successful. I think having a proper regional television vice, rather than the phoney sort of thing we they had before, has been a very good development. More broadly, I am very proud of the role that Australian officials and the Australian people have played in responding to the impact of the tsunami. These bills are just part of that process. We, if I can put it this way, negotiated with or explained to the Indonesian government a $1 billion package at the time of the summit organised by President Yudhoyono. There is no doubt that this five year program will have a very significant impact, and I am optimistic that it will work very successfully. We are planning to have the inaugural meeting of the joint commission next Thursday afternoon when we hold the Australia-Indonesia ministerial forum. During the course of that meeting we will really get the whole process under way. There was a report on the front of the Melbourne Age today, and I think the member for Griffith may have mentioned this. Of course, he would have jumped on it and said, ‘This shows that Australia's and Indonesia's relationship has almost completely disintegrated.' My advice to shadow ministers and members of the opposition, having been in opposition for a long time, is: don't go the hyperbole too much, because it tends not to be believed by anybody-and for good reason. This media report suggesting Australia and Indonesia are clashing over the provision of official Australian tsunami assistance is not not correct. Australia and Indonesia are in full agreement over the need to harmonise and coordinate donor efforts. In a meeting only yesterday between Australian officials and the Indonesian planning minister, who is quoted in this story-Sri Mulyani Indrawati-she did not express any concern about the $1 billion Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Develseropment. She expressed no concern about it at all, and I would not imagine that she would. In my experience in dealing with the Indonesians over this issue, they have been nothing but extremely grateful and positive about the whole program and the fact that it is a joint project. For our part, we are committed to ensuring accountability for how Australian taxpayers' money is spent. I know that members going back to their electorates-and I suppose that is particularly government members-want to be able to tell their constituents that the money is being spent properly. Australian assistance is reported, obviously, in the Indonesian budget process. As appropriate, Australia will work within and help build the capacity of Indonesia's existing administrative, financial, auditing, monitoring and evaluation systems. Indeed, we have seconded a senior Australian aid official to Indonesia's official aid coordination agency to provide assistance. So I am not quite sure how this story emerged on the front of a newspaper today, but I would not get excited about it. I think the Indonesians have been enormously grateful for the $1 billion worth of assistance and for what they know it will be able to achieve. Some people argue that we should provide the assistance multilaterally through UN and other agencies rather than doing it directly. Where we live next door to a country, as we do with Indonesia, we probably know the country a good deal better than a lot of the multilateral agencies and we are able to implement more effectively and with a greater degree of transparency and scrutiny our own aid programs on a bilateral basis. Of course, it is a bit different with Sri Lanka, which is further away and about which we know less compared to Indonesia-although we do know Sri Lanka pretty well. So we have placed more emphasis on using multilateral agencies there. But in the case of Indonesia, think it has made sense to have the bilateral project and to implement it in the way that we are. Let me conclude by saying this: during his speech the member for Griffith ranged far and wide about the horrifically bad relationship Australia has with Asia, how the Howard government hates Asia and all this sort of stuff. Again, my advice to the opposition is to try to follow what is actually going on rather than try to spin some kind of a line to the public that is just not credible. We have worked very closely with Indonesia and other countries in the region, but of course from time to time we have difficulties because our national interests do not always coincide. Make no mistake about it, on this side of the House we always stand up for Australia. So sometimes there are disagreements with other countries. The member for Griffith always comes out in support of the other country which has a disagreement with us. It is not right. He should not do that; it makes him look weak and it makes the opposition look weak. I got out of bed today and came to the parliament with a determination to try to help our opposition to look better, because they say that you have good government when you have good opposition. At the moment we have a very poor opposition, and if you were better then we might even be better ourselves-if that is at all possible. You have to think of the logic of these things. The member for Griffith should be more forensic and more credible in his attacks on the government. For example, he says that the doctrine of regional pre-emption has melted Australia's relations with the region. That is not right. But, since he attacks this notion of pre-emption, what we would like to know from the opposition is the answer to this question: in what circumstances, if the opposition became the government, would it I not take action to stop Australians being attacked? What are the circumstances that the opposition would articulate when it would not take action to protect Australians? I would like to know the answer to that question, because that is what the opposition is saying-that there are certain circumstances in which it would not act to protect Australians. Otherwise you would say that, in extremis, if the worse came to the worse, you would take pre-emptive action. But if you say that you would never take pre-emptive action, then there are some circumstances where you would not act to protect Australians. The trouble is that you have not thought this through. You are out there making these claims-they come from the Guardian, the New York Times or Robert Fisk in the Independent. Do not worry, I go through the web sites of these newspapers. I know what they are all saying. This sort of la la land leftie stuff is unfortunately picked up here in this country by our own Australian Labor Party. I could understand it if it were Bob Brown and the Green Left, but the Labor Party are supposed to be a party that one day could become the government. It is very important to think about what you are saying and what the implications are of what you are saying. The fact is that we have done an immense amount in our relationship with Indonesia and with Asia and there is no question of the government's strong commitment to Asia. The Prime Minister was up in Vientiane in November attending the historic ASEANAustralian summit. He would not have been invited to the ASEAN-Australian summit if Asia did not want to deal with Australia-as Paul Keating said they would not. We held the interfaith dialogue in December last year in Yogyakarta, where we brought together religious leaders from throughout the region to help encourage and develop a sense of tolerance and understanding between the different religious groups in the region. We have Muslim exchange programs. We provide an enormous amount of assistance to the Indonesians as well as to other countries in the region in the area of counter-terrorism. One of the things you hear from the opposition over the Iraq issue is that we should be bringing people back here and concentrating on our own region, as though Australia is a country weaker and smaller, even, than, say, New Zealand and as though we cannot actually do more than one thing at a time. If the opposition bothered to look through some of the press releases we put out and the public comments we have made, they would find that Australia does a tremendous amount in the area of counterterrorism in the region. For example, we have basically set up the Jakarta Centre for Law Enforcement Cooperation, at a cost of $36.8 million over five years. There are excellent relations between the AFP and our intelligence agencies and the Indonesians. I think it is very important for the opposition, if they want to win the confidence of the public, to make sure that they are credible in the arguments they put-and some of their arguments, I am afraid, are really not too credible. The opposition, apparently, are opposed to the Australian Maritime Identification System. The opposition are opposed to us finding out the provenance of ships coming to Australia, the content of those ships and the crew size before they get here. It is all very well to do it for aircraft before they take off to fly to Australian airports, but apparently we should not be doing it with ships. Has the member for Griffith actually thought this through? Is he opposed to the Australian Maritime Identification System? I am sure the shadow minister for transport does not agree with that. In conclusion, I am delighted to support these bills. Other than the member for Griffith, who had his usual rant about the horrific Howard fascist government, the contributions from members opposite, as well as from my colleagues on this side of the House, have been very positive and constructive. We provided this aid package not in order to buy favours in Indonesia, not in order to build up our bilateral relationship with Indonesia but because we thought it was the right thing to do. We thought there was enormous suffering in Indonesia and that, given our proximity, the strong relationship we have with Indonesia and the history of that relationship, we are a country with the capacity to act. We have lived through an era of great economic prosperity in this country and long may it last. We are a rich country. Even our poor are very rich compared with the Indonesian poor. To provide assistance to them in this terrible time is the least we could do. It is not about buying favours or about engagement with East Asia; it is about the common humanity which has been expressed by members of this parliament on both sides in this debate. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND
text: by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA Public Accounts and Audit Committee

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Paterson) (12.57 p.m.)As Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I ask leave of the House to make a statement in connection with the committee's responsibilities relating to the appointment of the Auditor-General as per section 8A of the Public Accounts and Audit Committee Act. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Under section 8A of the Public Accounts and Audit Committee Act 1951, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit has the responsibility to approve or reject a proposed recommendation by the Prime Minister for the appointment to the office of Auditor-General. This is the first occasion on which my committee has exercised this important statutory obligation, it having been enacted during the tenure  rett. The Auditor-General is an independent officer of the parliament, so it is both appropriate and important that my committee has the power to scrutinise and, if it deems necessary, reject a nomination to this position. I am pleased to rise on this occasion to indicate that on 7 March the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit met and gave unanimous approval to the appointment of Mr Ian MCPhee as Auditor-General. The appointment has been approved this morning by the Executive Council. Mr MCPhee is a dedicated and highly competent person who brings a wealth of experience to the position. He was formerly a long-serving employee of the Australian National Audit Office, gaining experience at the highest levels of the organisation as Deputy Auditor-General from 1998 to 2003. He left the Audit Office to become a Deputy Secretary in the Department of Finance and Administration. Mr MCPhee expressed to the committee his views on the positive role of the Audit Office as a value adder. He recognised that the most efficient way of achieving outcomes is through the provision of advice in a cooperative, rather than an oppositional, spirit. Auditors are not an enemy whose role it is to obstruct government agencies and departments. It is not merely the role of the Auditor-General and his staff to scrutinise and criticise government agencies for inefficiencies, but to educate through the publication of better practice guides. However, the primary responsibility of the Audit Office is to ensure that government agencies and departments operate efficiently and effectively, while meeting all the compliance standards that are required of publicly funded agencies. In this the Auditor-General and his staff must operate without fear or favour, and Mr MCPhee's record is a testament to his abilities in this regard. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, which I have the honour to chair, and the Audit Office are complementary instruments, through which procedures in the expenditure of public funds are scrutinised and held accountable. Both organisations work best when they enjoy a close working relationship. We look forward to reinforcing and building upon the already strong lines of communication between the JCPAA and the Audit Office during Mr MCPhee's stewardship. On behalf of the committee, I congratulate Mr MCPhee on his appointment and express our complete confidence in his abilities to ensure that the Australian public gets value for its money. Finally, I wish to acknowledge the achievements of the outgoing Auditor as Commonwealth Auditor-General since May 1995. He could be said to be the first truly independent Auditor-General. It was during Mr Barrett's tenure that the Auditor General Act 1997 was enacted-following, of course, a 1996 report by my committeemarking a new era for the ANAO. The act established the Auditor-General as an independent officer of the parliament, gave him more autonomy over the budget of the ANAO and gave him a mandate to audit all Commonwealth entities. During Mr Barrett's time, the Audit Office has proven to be a vital instrument through which government agencies and departments have been held accountable to the parliament. I wish him well for the future and again congratulate Mr MCPhee on his appointment to this important office.

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-As Deputy Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I am pleased to support the chair, the member for Paterson, in his report to the House of the appointment of Ian MCPhee as the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General position is a prestigious and powerful one. It rightly attracts the respect of all members of this parliament and all those entrusted with the parliament's work in government departments, authorities and agencies. Although this respect may be linked to the legal power that attaches to the position, in the case of Mr Ian MCPhee the respect will clearly attach to the quality and competence of the man himself. Respect will also particularly be extended to Mr MCPhee because of his ability to work consultatively and in an advisory capacity to bring about shared commitment to best practice and continuous improvement. Ian MCPhee has dedicated his professional life to service of the public. He is proudly a public servant and his devotion and competence in that role have been recognised by his peers with Mr MCPhee having been awarded the Public Service Medal in 2002 for outstanding public service to public sector accounting and auditing and the development of industry accounting standards. In 2004 he also became a fellow of the Certified Practicing Accountants, receiving their meritorious service award for his significant contribution and distinguished service to CPA Australia. Internationally, Mr MCPhee is regarded as a leader of reform committed to bringing about continuous improvement in accountability, accounting standards and administrative performance in the public sector. For ordinary Australians, the Auditor-General is basically their man on the job, keeping government honest and giving the public confidence that the money they contribute to the government's purse will be spent prudently and correctly in order to maximise the opportunity for all Australians to benefit from the nation's prosperity. With that obligation in mind, the committee unanimously endorsed the appointment of Ian MCPhee as the next Auditor-General of Australia. In doing so they acknowledged their confidence that Mr MCPhee would be able to continue in the strong tradition of  act independently, impartially and without fear or favour to deliver best outcomes for the people he will serve-the men and women of Australia. I also think the committee know a good numbers man when they see one, and Ian MCPhee comes to the position after having worked in the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian National Audit Office and the Department of Finance and Administration. On behalf of opposition members of JCPAA, I sincerely congratulate Mr MCPhee on his appointment and look forward to working with him and the ANAO in performing our complementary duties. I also take this opportunity to acknowledge the excellent work of  General position, knowing that he has developed the ANAO to a level of operation admired and respected internationally. The committee and I wish him a healthy and productive future. Finally, I draw attention to the challenges that face our new Auditor-General in this 21st century. Not only have the numbers got bigger, but expectations and demands have risen. Today government operates in an increasingly globalised market environment shaped by continuing technology advances. Government in this century is more complex and more intertwined with the private sector than ever before, making accountability more and more about shared standards and shared performance. Both the Auditor General and the Audit Office face the challenge of assisting government departments, exercising contracts and tenders sometimes worth billions of dollars in the marketplace, to gain the best value for money. The move to international accounting standards, compliance and regulatory frameworks also impacts on the work of the ANAO who take on our an important best-practice development role with departments and agencies. In the current information technology and data dependent work environment, the Audit Office is increasingly involved in the tracking of complex electronic management systems to gauge efficiency and effectiveness of practice. The move to shared systems and shared data also poses particular challenges for Audit, but the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit believe Mr MCPhee is up to the task ahead. Again, I congratulate Mr MCPhee on his appointment as Auditor-General and offer him the support of the committee in maximising the work of the Australian National Audit Office and the Australian government. NA NA BILL 2005 Report from Main Committee Bill returned from Main Committee without amendment; certified copy of the bill presented. Ordered that this bill be considered immediately. Bill agreed to. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: MARINE SCIENCE AMENDMENT
text: Flinders-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (1.07 p.m.)-by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA NA (DETERRENCE OF ILLEGAL FOREIGN FISHING) BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Mr Truss: That this bill be now read a second time. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR (Corio) (1.07 p.m.)-The Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005 is an important piece of legislation which aims to strengthen the Commonwealth powers in relation to the investigation and detention of suspected illegal fishers, particularly in the Torres Strait, ensure a seamless transfer of detainees between fisheries and immigration detention. This legislation has been made necessary by the government's past failures to curb illegal fishing activities in northern Australian waters generally. As I understand it, the legislation is a precursor to the establishment of a proposed 250-bed migration detention facility in Darwin for alleged illegal fishers. Despite the government's intense rhetoric about border security and its crass manipulation of the issue for political purposes, particularly in relation to refugees, the documents that became available in 2004 have shown that the problem of illegal fishing is out of hand and that the government's policy of administrative seizure was having little practical effect on preventing illegal fishing in Australia's fishing zone to the north. I can recall that in 2002 the minister issued a quite extraordinary press release in which he said that the government was winning the war against illegal fishing-we all know that that was nonsense. The process of administrative seizure was basically allowing foreign illegal fishers to be temporarily detained and to have some of their gear confiscated. Their boats were pointed back towards the open seas and they were told to skedaddle out of Australia's fishing zone. The government was not really serious about this issue, although its rhetoric was very intense. We on this side of the House dubbed it at the time the government's ‘tag and release' policy. That would have a particular resonance for the fisherpersons in this House and of course for the member opposite, the member for Flinders, who would be aware of that particular fishing terminology. It really was a tag and release policy: grab the boat, interview the captain, seize a bit of gear, then turn the boat around and point it out towards the open seas. Of course, that is not good enough if you are going to be fair dinkum to about the issue of border security. Despite having known of the extent of the problem for years, the government has really been tardy in tackling the problem head-on in a comprehensive way. As we say in political parlance, the government has talked the talk but it has not walked the walk. This bill forms part of several measures being introduced by the government to deal with illegal fishing and, from our point of view, some of these measures are long overdue. In the minister's second reading speech, we are informed that, firstly, extra resources are being provided to AFMA to apprehend and prosecute illegal fishers and, secondly, additional resources are also being provided to AQIS to enhance its ability to monitor and protect Australia from quarantine risks associated with apprehended vessels. Of course, in addition to that, this bill engineers processing and detention arrangements for illegal fishers in the sense that they are being standardised to provide seamless deportation arrangements for illegal fishers. The bill encompasses three pieces of legislation: the Fisheries Management Act, the Torres Strait Fisheries Act and the Migration Act. According to the government, it is aimed at making the Torres Strait Fisheries Act consistent with the Fisheries Management Act, in relation to the powers currently exercised under the latter act, to ensure that adequate time is allowed to investigate alleged offences. Another aim of the legislation, and perhaps the central focus of it, is create a fishing detention regime under both the Fisheries Management Act and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act that is broadly consistent with the legal requirements of immigration detention arrangements. These are objectives that the opposition certainly does not quibble about. However, it is important that, in the process of achieving administrative and legal consistency across agencies and across jurisdictions, the parliament is mindful of the need to adequately scrutinise any proposals that seek to extend the exercise of legal powers of enforcement officers. As stated previously, the overall aim of this bill is to achieve consistency between the fisheries detention regime and immigration detention arrangements. Under the Fisheries Management Act, foreign fishers are detained if they are suspected of illegally fishing in Australia's waters. They are automatically granted an enforcement visa which enables fisheries officers to bring them into the migration zone for further investigation and possibly prosecution. It is at this particular point that the provisions of authority of the Migration Act come into play. After that enforcement visa expires, a person assumes the status of an unlawful non-citizen and is then detained under the Migration Act. There are many key elements of this bill, and I want to address their implications further in my speech today. Firstly, the investigation and detention powers under the Torres Strait Fisheries Act are brought broadly into line with those of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. Secondly, the bill creates a new class of officer who may exercise powers related to fisheries detention. This will allow employees and contractors of AFMA and DIMIA, who are specifically appointed by the fisheries minister, to exercise detention powers under fisheries legislation. Labor successfully opposed a similar attempt last to year to grant powers as quarantine officers to contractors and their employees. We have consulted widely on this matter with our union colleagues, and the CPSU has expressed its concern about this particular provision. The bill specifically gives fisheries officers the powers that immigration officers currently have in relation to searching and screening of people detained as unlawful non-citizens in an immigration detention facility, including the capacity to conduct searches and strip searches, and to screen persons and visitors. Also under the bill, authorised officers will be given power to collect personal identity information from detainees for the purpose of identifying repeat offenders and facilitating prosecutions. This information may be passed on to other agencies responsible for detention, welfare and the repatriation of detainees. Under this bill, the offence of obstructing an officer will be broadened, and increased penalties will apply. The power of officers to search persons on foreign fishing boats and to examine and take possession of items that may constitute evidence on foreign fishing boats will also be clarified in this piece of legislation. The opposition welcomes that. As I understand it, a new provision will be inserted into the Fisheries Management Act and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act to prevent certain legal actions against those assisting officers of the Commonwealth by persons on vessels that are subject to the directions of authorised officer. Also, the forfeiture provisions of the Fisheries Management Act in relation to fishing gear and boats will be extended to the Torres Strait Fisheries Act. In the broad sweep of measures in this bill there is a genuine attempt by the government to bring some consistency to the fisheries management and migration detention regimes. Of course, that is welcomed. As I said previously, this problem emerged as far back as 2002, and the minister made the proud boast that the government was on top of the problem. It certainly was not on top of the legal and administrative arrangements-and achieving consistency in them-or it would have tackled those measures at that particular time. We know that the government has been tardy in a whole range of legislative areas, but no more so than in this area. I would have expected that the government would have been able to perform a little better given its rhetoric about how sincere it is about broader protection. There are a range of very good reasons why Australia needs to adequately resource its border protection arrangements in relation to illegal fishing. It is our right under international law to take all reasonable steps necessary to preserve the integrity of our national borders. In addition, we live in difficult times, with the very real threat of terrorism in our region. The Bali and Jakarta bombings were a gruesome reminder to all Australians that some fanatics simply do not respect national borders, and to secure the nation we need adequate border protection arrangements. In addition, in this era of great global mobility, there is an ever present threat that severe economic and environmental disruption and dislocation will be caused by the introduction of exotic pests and diseases that we do not have in Australia. Therefore, our quarantine protection arrangements, which an are designed to protect key rural industries and the biodiversity of Australia's unique physical environment, need to be adequately resourced and professionally administered. Similarly, we live in an unfortunate era where highly organised crime cartels engage in everything from piracy on the high seas to gun-running and trade in illicit drugs. This is a very serious problem, and in relation to politics I know of some pirates in the government ranks. The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry effectively pirated many of the policies on agriculture that I put to the Australian people years out from the election. Be that as it may, the odd pirate of policies in the government ought not to deter us from the important task of securing Australia's borders. The task of detection and prosecution of these criminal elements is an extremely important but difficult task for a nation with such an extensive coastline. All of this requires a high degree of sophistication to respond adequately to these threats, and a degree of professionalism and managerial expertise in the coordination of the various agencies involved in the border security task-namely, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, Australian Customs, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, the Australian Federal Police and the immigration department. I note the presence in the House today of the honourable member for Corangamite. As I have said in previous debates, there must be something fishy going on when the honourable member for Corangamite comes into this place! I have said in this place before that the honourable member would not know the difference between a piece of flake and a fish patty-and I meant it. It is good to see the honourable member for Corangamite in the chamber. We share part of the Australian coastline in our electorates and we know that it is very important that illegal fishing dressed at both the state and federal levels. As the honourable member for Corangamite knows, illegal fishing is a problem along the Victorian coastline, particularly in relation the pirating of abalone stocks. Far be it from me to categorise the member for Corangamite as a bit of a Captain Hook-an old pirate-because he is a very independent member, but it is good to see him in the chamber taking an interest in these matters. Apart from the considerations that I have just referred to, there are sound economic reasons for Australia to ensure that we adequately protect our interests in the Australian fishing zone. All around Australia-in my electorate, in the electorate of the honourable member for Corangamite and in other electorates-the fishing industry creates employment, generates domestic and export income and is the basic block on which the sustainability of many coastal and regional communities is built. The gross value of production of the Australian fishing industry stands at around $2.3 billion, and around $1.8 billion of that is exported. The total annual catch is in the region of 250,000 tonnes and is valued at around $856 million-that includes rock lobsters, which are worth $460 million; prawns, which are worth $355 million; tuna, which is worth $305 million; and abalone, which is worth $212 million. So this is a very important industry for Australia's export effort and our standard of living. It is an economic fact that the greater part of the industry comes from the exploitation of fish stocks around our coastline and in our oceans. Australia has international legal responsibilities, under treaty and bilateral arrangements, to manage fishery resources in a responsible and sustainable way. I referred earlier to the Torres Strait Fisheries Act and the treaty arrangements that Australia has in place with the government of Papua New Guinea in managing the Torres Strait Prois adtected Zone to adequately protect the precious fish resources in that zone. We also have a community responsibility to ensure that these northern fisheries are available to to Indigenous Australians for their economic use and to sustain their cultures, their economies and the lifestyles of their communities. The incursion of illegal fishers into the fisheries in our north is creating impacts that adversely affect fish stocks in these areas. I refer the House to the Bureau of Rural Sciences Fishery Status Report 2002-03, which provides the government with an independent assessment of the status of fish stocks managed by the Australian government. This is a very important report. It says that, of the 70 principal species classified, 16 were classified as ‘over-fished', 16 as ‘fully-fished', four as ‘under-fished' and 34 as ‘uncertain'. In the Northern Prawn Fishery, banana prawns are categorised as ‘fully-fished', brown tiger prawns as ‘over-fished' and grooved tiger prawns as ‘fully-fished'. The Torres Strait lobster fishery is categorised as ‘over-fished' and the prawn fishery as ‘fullyfished'. So the balance is rather precarious in many of the fisheries, particularly in our north, and illegal fishers exacerbate the problem we have in achieving the sustainability of the resource. As the number of illegal fishing incursions has significantly increased, so has the technical sophistication of the fishers themselves. As sought-after resources become scarce, they become more valuable. When this occurs, the money and the technological effort being put into the illegal task also increases. That leads to greater efficiencies by the illegal fishers, which in turn leads to the magnified adverse impact of the activity on already stretched resources. While Labor support the general thrust of the bill, I want to raise a couple of concerns we have about the framing of this legislation. The appointment of detention officers is dealt with under schedule 1A, part 1, division 3. This provision allows the minister to appoint by instrument a person or members of a class or group of people to be detention officers. This will allow for the creation of a new class of officer with certain limited powers of detention under the Fisheries Management Act. The explanatory memorandum to this bill says: It is envisaged that employees and contractors DIMIA and AFMA will be appointed as detention officers under the Fisheries Management Act 1991 in the same way that employees and contractors are currently employed under the Migra- officers. tion Act 1958. Labor has a problem with giving contractors-that is, people who are not directly responsible to the Commonwealth as employees-the powers granted to detention officers elsewhere in this bill. These include the power to search and confiscate property. We have no problem with Commonwealth employees having these powers, as they have clear lines of responsibility, through the department, to the minister and eventually to this parliament. They can clearly be held to account for their actions and are subject to directions from senior officers and the minister. Similarly, we would have no problem giving these powers to employees of the states and territories because they also are clearly accountable and are subject to direction by their senior officers. But we have always had a problem in this portfolio area of extending police-like powers to contractors, who are certainly not trained to undertake the task. The issue came up last year when the government sought to bring in legislation that would have allowed the minister to appoint any Tom, Dick or Harry as a quarantine officer. On that occasion Labor successfully argued that it was not appropriate to appoint contactors-people who were not directly accountable to the department, the minister and this parliament-as quarantine officers. We argued at the time that if the minister needed greater flexibility in appointing quarantine officers he should only appoint those who would be subject to clear lines of public accountability such as other federal or state public servants and police officers. On that occasion the government finally saw the sense of Labor's arguments and came to of agree with us. The quarantine legislation eventually went through this parliament last year with a provision allowing the minister to appoint private contactors as quarantine The provisions of this bill are somewhat similar to those that were originally in the quarantine legislation. It is mainly for this reason that Labor arranged to refer the bill to a Senate committee to allow the issue of the granting of these wide powers to contactors, who may well be subject to a lesser level of accountability for these actions than are public servants, to be examined. We will await the outcome of that inquiry before determining Labor's position on any possible amendments to this legislation. With regard to the provision of legal assiswell. tance, Labor welcomes the fact that under the proposed new section 24 of the act a detainee must be provided with access to legal advice. However, I am concerned that there is nothing in this piece of legislation that requires officials to inform detainees that they have the right to access reasonable facilities for obtaining legal advice. I am advised that section 23G of the Crimes Act places an obligation on an investigating officer to inform suspects of their rights, and places the onus on fisheries detention officers to do the same. However, I urge the government to give consideration to amending this bill to incorporate a requirement that detainees be informed of their rights to access legal advice. I think this is sensible and it feeds into that provision in the bill which has as its aim the protection of officers who are entrusted with these tasks under law to protect these fisheries. It may be possible to do this by adding a note to the clause in the bill that deals with the rights of detainees to legal assistance. The vast majority of detainees will have little understanding of Australian law and practices, and it is important that they are informed of their rights under Australian law where practicable. I understand it is not uncommon to include such provisions in legislation, even were the rights specified under the Crimes Act also to apply. I urge the government to do the same in this bill. This is an important piece of legislation. In summing up, I reiterate what I said earlier on in this debate: the problem has not gone away; indeed, it has increased. We have had thousands of reports of illegal fishing in our waters to our north in particular. Many of those may well have been multiple sightings, but we do know that the number of vessels apprehended and detained has increased. We know also that the level of sophistication of illegal fishing has certainly improved as So the weights are really on the government, in this particular legislation and in general policy, to ensure that Australia's borders are made secure. The legislation we have before us goes a considerable way to achieving that objective. I do not have any problem with saying that. I simply say that this problem was evident in 2002, and achieving some degree of administrative and legal consistency across the various agencies and jurisdictions is a matter that this I thought would have been in this parliament before March 2005. This legislative task should have been undertaken years ago, but the government really was not serious about the issue. It was serious about the political rhetoric used for its own political advantage but it really was not serious about getting on top of this issue. At least the now infamous tag and release policy that we had in our northern fisheries has in some way been addressed by this piece of legislation. The opposition will be supporting its passage through this House. I have already indicated that we will, in the other place, refer this to a committee for further finetoothcombing. We will examine in minute detail the provisions of this legislation and we will give people interested in this the opportunity of contributing, especially on those dimensions relating to the legal rights of people when they are detained and the rights of Commonwealth officers in exercising the task of apprehension and detention. All of those particular matters will be subject to the professional scrutiny of the Senate. If there are matters arising out of that that require further legislative attention we will pursue those. We hope in good faith that the government will examine the output of that process because, at the end of the day, we want the best set of arrangements to ensure that Australia's borders are adequately protected. Let the people of Australia be in no doubt at all about the Australian Labor Party's commitment to border security. What we will not do, though, is play politics with the issue. We want good outcomes. We hope that with this legislation we can walk some way along that path.

Speaker: Dr JENSEN
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I was somewhat bemused and amused at the member for Corio's strident speech about the government's lack of response in terms of border security. When I look at the opposition's record in terms of border security I find the amount of flip-flops, backflips, front flips and however you want to put it flips actually quite staggering. They must be chafing in some of their nether regions from sitting on the fence. I find it quite interesting that the member, in speaking about the inadequacy of the government's response in terms of illegal fishing, mentioned that the problem was identified in 2002. But what actually happened? The member was quite boastful about the fact that, when the government attempted to put in provisions to combat the illegal fishing regime, the opposition blocked the bill. He was quite proud about that. You wonder why he is now so stridently in favour of strong action as far as illegal fishing is concerned. Be that as it may, Labor has never been strong on border protection, as was in evidence in 2001 with the Tampa. But I will turn now to the bill before the House, the Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005. There have been problems with the differences in legislation with regard to the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984, the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Migration Act. The point with the Torres Strait Fisheries Act was that it came about in a similar manner to an agreement with Indonesia in 1974, and the purpose of these acts and agreements was essentially to allow traditional inhabitants to fish their traditional gions without prosecution. However, what we have at the moment is illegal fishing. In many cases it is from Indonesia, and media attention has been paid recently to fishing boats coming from Papua New Guinea and illegally fishing Australian waters. Clearly, many of these are commercial operations and could not be deemed to be traditional fishing by traditional inhabitants in any way, shape or form. However, the problem has been that the Torres Strait Fisheries Act and the Fisheries Management Act have not given adequate search and seizure powers. The bill before us is to close those loopholes and to bring the Torres Strait Fisheries Act, the Fisheries Management Act and the Migration Act into accord so that there is no conflict about what specific situation applies and what specific powers apply to specific officers. Originally the fisheries acts gave powers to detain but there was no provision for imprisonment, apart from when fines that had been imposed were not paid. Clearly, the acts were inadequate in that regard. The current bill specifies the types of officers who are allowed to detain illegal fishermen. It addresses discrepancies between powers relating to the forfeiture of items, be they items on the people themselves or, indeed, the boats that they use to engage in these illegal fishing activities. When an illegal fishing activity is detected, the boat will be boarded. It will be seized, and enforcement visas will be applied to the illegal fishermen so that they can be brought into Australia and thence charged. This bill will confirm the Commonwealth's ability to restrain people caught illegally fishing. Powers that have not traditionally been given to officers who have detained these fishermen in fishing boats have been, for example, the ability to search or to check the identity of people that have been caught. reWhere there is reasonable suspicion, the bill allows the officers concerned to strip search the illegal fishermen, but only to the level deemed necessary in order to search for what is suspected. This is a very important part of the bill in that many of these fishermen potentially could carry arms. It is perfectly sonable that officers who are conducting enforcement operations should have a reasonable ability to determine how much of a threat to their personal safety these illegal fishermen could be. As I have stated, these strip searches are to be carried out only if there is reasonable suspicion that there is a potential risk. In terms of identification of illegal fishermen, the current acts do not allow for going into detailed ID checks. This bill allows provision for taking fingerprints from illegal fishermen, putting them through metal detectors, doing X-rays and getting signatures. However, it is important to note that these ID provisions do not apply to people under 15 or to people who are otherwise incapable. An important provision of this bill is that it makes exercising officers arresting illegal fishermen immune from legal action if they are acting in good faith. This is an important provision; otherwise there would probably be a great amount of litigation in this regard. It is important to note as well that part of the reason for this bill is that there has been court activity in the past concerning the apprehension of illegal fishermen. Under the current Fisheries Management Act there is no screening allowed. Clearly, this is inadequate. People who appear to be illegal fishermen may indeed be more than that-for example, under the guise of being illegal fishermen, they may be attempting to get to Australia to conduct terrorist activity. The identification provisions include the videoing of suspects. An important issue that has been brought to light in cases where mobile phones have video cameras and so on is that it is clearly an abuse of those videos. Under this legislation the ID process allows videos to be taken. However, if people do not have adequate authority to view the video or they use it for illegal viewing, a two-year reasentence could apply to them. It is important in this regard that only reasonable and explicitly stated disclosure of ID be allowed between authorised officers. We do not want the situation where videos or other ID information that may be compromising is allowed to be accessed by all and sundry. In conclusion, I would like to say that this bill has been required for a while. It brings into line the Migration Act, the Fisheries Management Act and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act but it still allows for traditional fishing to take place.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT
text: I can confirm that the opposition does support the Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005. In general terms the legislation, as the previous speaker indicated, seeks to ensure that the investigation, detention and forfeiture provisions of the Torres Strait Fisheries Act-which I will call the Torres Strait act-and the Fisheries Management Act are in line with those in the Migration Act 1958. At present, fishing in the Torres Strait is regulated by the Torres Strait act, whereas elsewhere fishing is regulated by the Fisheries Management Act. While the provisions in these acts are similar, they are not identical, particularly in respect of some significant coercive search and seizure powers. This bill significantly enhances the powers of fisheries officers to detain and investigate suspected illegal foreign fishers and clarifies the powers fisheries officers may exercise. It is a welcome step, we believe, towards streamlining Australia's legislative response to preventing illegal foreign fishing. Australia has faced an influx of foreign fishing arrivals for literally hundreds of years. In fact when Matthew Flinders arrived in the region that was to become Darwin, he found villages where people from Indonesia were drying fish and obviously had been doing so for some considerable time. This is a particularly significant issue for Australia. We have responsibilities and rights in our exclusive economic zone, which covers some 16 million square kilometres. It is an area more than twice the size of the land mass of continental Australia. It ranges across some 60 degrees of latitude and 100 degrees of longitude.
